I like their exercise for data analytics learners, they are pratical and helps me review what I actually learn.
The info and structure is definitely great but the tutor (and i heard mentors too) tend to be very hit or miss and don’t talk and help you as much as they should.

Enrolling in the CareerFoundry Web Development program has proven to be a remarkable experience, largely due to the outstanding support system provided. 
My tutor has been an unwavering guide, offering assistance, answering questions, and providing encouragement throughout the learning process. His personalized feedback on assignments adds a valuable touch to the overall experience.
Equally impressive is the knowledgeable mentor who checks achievement projects and provides crucial insights during online meetings. This dynamic duo of tutor and mentor has significantly enhanced my understanding of complex web development concepts.
CareerFoundry goes beyond individual assistance, offering a robust support infrastructure. Student advisors, slack as a peer platform, and forums create a collaborative environment, addressing challenges that come with the territory of web development.
While web development demands rigorous self-study, the support from CareerFoundry makes the journey more manageable and enjoyable. 
The emphasis on personal effort is clear, but with such a dedicated team, navigating through the intricacies of web development becomes a rewarding experience. 
CareerFoundry not only equips students with technical skills but also fosters a supportive learning environment that sets it apart.

I am learning a lot in this at Careerfoundry and it is teaching me the whole UX Design process and how I can implement it in the jobs that I do. This course also upgraded additional skills that I missed when I worked and did various Case studies. I am also happy to have a mentor who helps me not only with the course but also with the values of how I can adapt them when I perform as a UX Product Designer

I have enjoyed the Hands-on experience I get from the format of the course, it gets me familiar with the tools for my trade and lets me simulate real-life scenarios and case studies. I believe this is a great way to learn transferable skills and habits that I will use for a very long and fulfilling career.

My experience with Career Foundry in their UX Course has been great so far because the lessons are understandable and well organized. I also feel supported by my tutor & mentor. Career Foundry makes self-paced learning doable and the team is responsive.

I'm currently halfway through the program. I'm loving it so far! I've learned a lot, and the exercises are always relevant and serve as great examples. My tutor is really helpful and encouraging as well, and always answers my questions promptly. All the provided reading material is also relevant and interesting. I've just started the job placement part of the course, and I'm excited to see how it goes. Once I finish this course, I have no doubt I will feel more confident about my future interviews and entering the workforce as a data analyst.

This is really a great experience till now. 
I am learning so much in the course & the course is also very well constructed. Simple language.
Course is really well designed. Intuitive platform. Tutors and Mentors answer quickly. Feeling excited !!!

I am happy with CareerFoundry Course. My Tutor and Mentor are helpful and timely. i like the course structure and material and end of the course i will have projects for my portfolio.
Thanks CareerFoundry

The course gives a good idea of all activities in the field of product management and forces us to use a high amount of new tools within the exercises. I found a deep amount of new tools and methods within the course.

I'm currently enrolled in an online UX course as part of my career change, and the experience has been nothing short of empowering. Even though I haven't completed the course yet, I'm compelled to share my positive impressions.
The curriculum is both comprehensive and relevant, providing a holistic understanding of UX principles. The ongoing nature of the course allows me to pace myself, ensuring a deep dive into each topic without feeling overwhelmed.
I appreciate the practical focus, preparing me for the challenges that lie ahead. The ongoing support and resources, including networking opportunities, make this course stand out. 
In a nutshell, if you're considering a career change into UX design, this course is a promising avenue for growth.
I’m very pleased with this course. My mentor and tutor are very helpful, always willing to help out and make things clear when I don’t understand something. I’m in the middle of the course

Do not waste your money on Career Foundry, and especially on their Web Dev program. It's a copy-paste exercise, their tutors and mentors must not be paid very well, as they are extremely useless and have little time for you. 
Of the study group I was in, we've all now given up on switching careers.
I had fun learning, but could have learnt the same at a fraction of the cost elsewhere on the internet.
The money back guarantee is of course pretty much impossible to get.

I've been enjoying this course and feel like there is a lot of support if you have questions or want to speak to your tutor or mentor.  It is a very hands-on approach, you complete tasks after each lesson which is very digestible and easy to follow along.  You can go at your own pace, which is what I need while working full time.

My time with this boot camp has been great, the program is pretty detailed and gives you the time to learn a lot of different skills that you'll be able to use in the workforce. I have such a great tutor and mentor, both are individuals who clearly want me to succeed and do my best. Whenever I need help, it's easy to get in contact with my tutor or to reach out to peers taking the course with me. I enjoy the independence the program offers as it encourages students to use problem-solving skills as you would in the real workforce.

It is well written course but I found it really hard to understand tasks and apply after spending hours as a beginner.
When I asked help from the mentor, all he does is telling me to search and watch more videos. There is not much support out there. 
It is impossible to complete tasks when you have already job.
When you are signing up, they sound like there will be lots of support.
Job guarantee is only if you can finish the course in 10-months which gives you a lot of pressure.
Waste of a lot of money.

The material is very interesting and uses lots of examples so it’s easy to wrap my head around the concepts. I like that I had the choice of two capstone projects so I can tailor my course experience to my career goals and previous experience. The platform is user-friendly and I feel I have the support I need to learn. Tons of resources and thoughtful feedback on each task. Would highly recommend CF!

Career Foundry is setup where there are multiple achievements. Each achievement teaches you a specific topic which is crucial for that role. At the end of each achievement is a project that requires you to use the skill set you have learned. Building up to the project are exercises - each one building you up in knowledge on that topic. These exercises generally take 1-2 hours to read through, then 1-3 hours to do each task required; Of course the timing will be very individualized. If you are doing this course I would recommend you truly understand each exercise as you are doing them, not just to power through the task. At the end when you do each project record a video detailing what you went through and how you got the results that you do. This will serve as content for employers but also for yourself. Careerfoundry is a very good online school, but its effectiveness will be completely up to the individual.

I enjoyed the product manager program from CareerFoundry so far. One of its standout features is the unique opportunity it provides to forge connections with industry experts/mentors, fostering invaluable relationships. Furthermore, the program nurtures a vibrant slack community where students can engage and collaborate with like-minded peers.
From a personal standpoint, the program's most prized attribute, in my opinion, is the unwavering support it extends when it comes to navigating the job market. Recognizing that networking can be a weak point for me, the guidance and assistance provided by career specialists have been instrumental in boosting my confidence and making me better equipped for the job search.

I truly enjoyed studying with CareerFoundry. I thoroughly selected this bootcamp looking at prices, reviews, course material, and I’m very happy with my decision.
 I like the way classes are structured and how material is presented, especially all of the additional resources and recently new suggestions on how to incorporate AI into course work. 
I also like all of the communication channels with my tutor, mentor and student advisors. I also like that they encourage interactions with other students. 
The only thing I would like to see more is more video instructions especially with it comes to practicing and developing certain skills within platforms. 
Other than that the course is truly great and I would certainly recommend it.
CareerFoundry gave me skills and resources to thrive in a new field.
Amazing experience with the mentors and tutors!

I'm currently on month two out of ten on the UX Design Program. I'm learning a lot about being a UX Designer and the exercises provide thorough information on the various aspects of being a UX Designer. The tasks really break down key points of the design process and help take you through the project you'll be doing. There's a lot to learn but Career Foundry gives you all the tools necessary to understand all the new information thrown at you. I come from a completely different background/career (BS in Animal Science, full-time Research Technician) and I was scared trying to learn a brand new career field. But I've enjoyed learning the field thus far and look forward to my future career in this fascinating industry.

Very happy with Career Foundry. I have learned so much and applying what I have learned to real world tasks makes the learning experience that much richer. My tutors and mentors have also made this experience incredible.
The feedback is great on each course and slack offers great interaction with the mentor and tutor

Very well structured UX program from Career foundry. Amazing tutor, mentor and student advisors.
I love the experience and the UX design course at Career Foundry. it's very well structured and guided. You don't feel alone because you can connect with the slack community and the student advisors are very supportive.

I have been really enjoying the boot camp! I am utilizing Career Foundry's boot camp, YouTube tutorials, and self teaching via learning courses.  While I am learning things through other methods just fine, I really would have experienced issues with staying on track and focusing in general without Career Foundry's course design.  The structure it provides gives my self learning a very supportive backbone and direction.  Most invaluable though, is the access to a mentor.  I find that I can write down questions throughout the week, from my learning, and they are sooooo friendly about it.  The amount of details they provide and the guidance and advice alone is worth the course fee.  I am almost halfway through and have not regretted any of it :)!

Complete waste of $$ when there are low cost and free programs available that are far superior in value to what CareerFoundry has to offer. The tutoring and support is almost nonexistent. Every time you ask a question you will most likely receive a link to a youtube video or website. You are paying $6000 to basically learn on your own which you can do just by watching and following youtube tutorials in the field. The certification is worthless when it comes to getting a job in the field. Better off investing in an accredited college or university program. Feedback, support, and communication methods in general are subpar.

This is an honest review from a graduate who finished in May, 2023. Sorry, but it's definitely not the quality I expected. The job guarantee is a joke, forget it. You never get your money back. I am very disappointed after the program when I realized how little value the certification has on the job market and among employers. The company has a fantastic Marketing team, but that's it. Don't believe everything they post on their website and blogs. It's just not true. The value is zero after graduation. Nobody cares about the projects built and you won't find a job, not even for under 20k€ a year. The course itself was okay, but the investment stands in no relation to the job market and present situation out there. Many fresh devs have no other choice than to take a voluntary internship (if somebody hires you).  You will by 99% don't get a job, your applications will be mainly ignored, if you don't have a computer science degree and a few years of relevant work experience as a developer yet. Mentor and tutor support is also very poor, although after three changes my third mentor was superb. I was just lucky. Otherwise you will probably get stuck in the course at some point as it gets difficult for at least 1,5 years if no longer. It's impossible to finish the course as a career changer without support from the assiged tutor in 3-6 month. For those who have already completed an acedemic degree in the field of IT with 1-2 years of relevant work experience, yes, it's gonna be a terrific course to sharpen your skills and specialize in. Otherwise, please keep your fingers away. 9000€ for the bootcamp is too pricy, rather invest in a university degree or consider another choice, if there's no time management issue. Don't believe stories like a taxi driver can make it in 3-9 month to a highly in demand Frontend or Fullstack Developer. It's not true.

The course has been teaching me everything I need to learn and grow as a data analyst. Since I joined it has been more of an advantage as I feel comfortable in doing tasks.
Pros
The tutors and mentors are helpful
Cons
Well no downside, you just have to stay motivated and keep working. The tasks keep you going and I like that.

CareerFoundry meets my needs as a parent who is making a transition in a career. Fully online and self-paced. Compared to other bootcamps I researched, the cost to go to CareerFoundry is one of the lowest. One thing I have enjoyed the most is the Student Advisor team. All-around, a great option!

I have been studying Data Analytics (DA) for more than 2 months and I can say that registering for the Program is the best decision I have made in the past few years. What I love the most is that I get so much motivation and inspiration from the fact that I am changing my life and career with every I exercise I submit. It makes me want to move on and do more and more to reach my goal in the end of the program (to find a job, of course ;). I love the stuff I'm learning and I can see how every thing I learn can be applicable in the real life. I am always looking forward to the next exercise, as after each of them I feel like I become more clever and cool. I was very surprised to learn that I am actually not so bad at math and statistics, as the exercises are created in such a way that I quickly understand what to do and how to apply it. However, it's not all about numbers, I am happy I can be creative with DA as well. I am also happy with my tutor and mentor. They are always there to help, respond quickly, and my tutor even gives me additional material to each exercise. 
Overall, I am more than happy and grateful to myself that I made a decision to start the program with CareerFoundry! I highly recommend it to everyone who wants to change their career or boost their knowledge in DA. 
Pros
- Very friendly and super professional tutor and mentor. Very supportive, reply very fast and give valuable advice (and additional material). They also always encourage me and help me fight my imposter syndrome :-)
 - Detailed, creative, logically structured exercises, saturated with valuable information. 
- Amazing tasks! - Supportive student advisors, always ready to help. 
- Price-quality ratio is adequate. Other schools that I looked at offered shorter programs for a higher price.
 - Interesting cases and stories in exercises (especially in the section about visualisations). 
Cons
- Sometimes there are small mistakes or inconsistencies which I always try to report to the Quality Assurance team. They sometimes disrupt my understanding and the workflow, and I have to ask my tutor for help, who usually agrees with me about the mistakes I find. It takes time to get a confirmation from my tutor, so I lose time. 
- Some sources are a bit outdated, although I understand that good sources have no expiration date.

I have found the format of CF to be incredibly good for my way of learning. Project oriented approach to learning, feeding you relevant information through each step of the process. I have had some communication issues with my tutor, and some of the submission criteria for tasks does not seem to be consistent but overall I am a huge fan of the process and course.

As a recent university graduate who was used to online courses and wanted to dive into a new specialization, I'm having a wonderful time with this course!  The tutors, mentors, and advisors provide constant support.  Since it's generally self-paced, it works well especially to those who want to be able to learn a new skill efficiently.  I have completed the main course and am now working with a very helpful career specialist through CareerFoundry to find my first UI/UX job :)

I can only talk about the UI and UX courses but I feel they are a great way into the industry.
I got my first role after 2 weeks of completing the course. I do feel that some people expect to be hand held all the way into a first job in the industry....that is not what the training is about.
Students need to read around the subject and tutors provided lots of additional resources an almost every submission.
But I feel for those who have unresponsive tutors or mentors. I asked for a change of mentor and it was sorted out straight away...so I feel you must take ownership of your training too.
Honestly I think this is a great way into the industry. Everyone whom I got to know in the UI and UX courses all got work within a few months of completing the course. One person took about 8 months but that was due to her location...but she worked hard and also succeeded.

I'm a total career changer, so it's not always easy for me, but the CareerFoundry team is there to help and advise.
The course material is clearly structured, and with every little achievement, I feel a bit more confident.
The vibrant Slack community is worth its weight in gold!

I started the course very perfectly and was happy learning frontend and basics. When I started the Full Stack Immersion, my first mentor couldn't help me because he didn't know what he was talking about. It seems like he didn't know anything about javascript. It took a month for him to help me with a simple issue with one of the features of a simple project. My second mentor was better, but the material was poorly updated or explained. I had to book a call with my mentor to explain some materials, and since he was super busy, it took a week or more to get help each time. After all, one of the reasons that I got this course with CareerFoundry was the job guarantee. Basically, without any experience and a related university degree, there would be no chance of getting a job, and collecting the requirements for getting a refund is a full-time job itself. I DO NOT recommend this school/Bootcamp to anyone who doesn't have related experience or degree. I applied for many jobs in many companies in the US and only got one interview in 7 months, and still no job.

I completed the UI Design course in 2022 and discovered that what I was taught did not meet the industry requirements for an entry-level job. The courses are text-based instruction with links to articles online. Each article has an assignment with a very low bar to passing - essentially just following instructions. I got limited feedback throughout the course, maybe about a sentence of feedback and a list of more links to articles on the topic. My tutor approved almost everything after the first try, and it was only sent back to me once because I forgot to include a component. 
After finishing the course, there's a career course that you need to complete in 1 month and start applying for jobs to qualify for the job guarantee. The course had something like 12 assignments, one of which was to create a website with all the case studies for the course. It took me about a month just to build my portfolio website. The course does not teach how to build a website so I had to watch youtube videos.  I finished the course in 2 months and thus was ineligible for the job guarantee. 
After I graduated, their advice for getting a job didn't work for me. I applied for jobs, networked in the field, and did a few volunteer projects to build up my portfolio. I went through about 4 career specialists because they kept switching me when the suggestions they gave were not working. The career specialists I worked with seemed frustrated with me and often behaved as if they did not believe I was doing the things I said I was doing. For example, one asked me to track my time and activities on the job search. I spent an extra hour or so each week doing this. When I submitted my results and asked for a meeting, I got a more detailed prompt for tracking my job search. When I submitted my more detailed report of what I did in the past few weeks, I was told to keep doing that every week.

At the beginning it started out ok and I was completing the coursework on time however, I soon noticed that if I had a question or came to a point where the content was not clear or there was information missing, I couldn't get help right away.
All I could do was send a message to the tutor and have to wait 24hrs for a response. The question could have been as simple as a yes/no response but I had to wait 24hrs just for that response. This immediately struck me as something disturbing and I began questioning the efficacy of this training. There were also many times when the course content was not clear; I had questions about what the exercise was trying to tell us but had to wait 24 hrs just to clarify what they were talking about.
Somehow I got over these hurdles and kept pushing forward. About half way through the program, my tutor took some vacation for about 6 weeks. CA assigned a replacement tutor that, for the most part, didn't really care or spend the time with the student to help them get questions answered.
I lost 6 weeks with the replacement tutor and could not finish an exercise that I had all but completed but I needed his assistance on a persistent error message I was getting.
After 6 weeks I was still on this same exercise and right around that time my tutor finally returned and found the problem within 24 hrs (of course I had to wait 24 hrs) but the point being that this showed the difference in the tutorial assistance I was receiving. Why couldn't the substitute tutor have found the solution in 24 hrs? It was either because he himself didn't have the knowledge to debug the program or he simply didn't care to spend the time with the student.
Next problem was with the mentor (different from the tutor I was talking about) for a certain exercise he was assigned to. Once again I reached the end of the exercise and had a connection error that I was unfamiliar with. I submitted my work with all the coding involved and he [the mentor] told me he couldn’t render it locally on his machine and asked me to get it working on my end before submitting it to him again.
I thought; Excuse me but what is the mentor’s purpose here? Why am I paying so much money for this assistance and he only tells me to go figure out by myself? I had finished the exercise but I was getting an error that could have been debugged if he spent the extra few minutes to find it.
So the mentor then went away on vacation for a week (more time lost in the program) and I turned to my tutor who had been very helpful all along. He responded within 24hrs to tell me the project was working on his end. He had no problem with it. It was working just fine. So I asked him if he could help me find out why it wasn’t working on my end. It must have been some setting or something that I was missing and he agreed to help me find it. He spent a few days on it but we still hadn’t come to a solution.
I had to be considerate of his time as well as this exercise was not even assigned to him originally so he was spending extra time to help me out aside from his regular work schedule. By that time however, the mentor had returned so I turned the question back to him and explained to him that my tutor was able to get it to render locally on his end and once again if he could help me find the reason it wasn’t rendering on my end. His response was the following:
"I would suggest have a call with him and share your screen and show him the issue you are having and see if he can help fix the issue since you said it is working for him. I am kind of busy to spend time on this to figure out what is the issue."
Once again I thought, are you sure you’re a mentor for this program? I’m paying for this assistance and your answer is to go to someone else for help?
Well, that was pretty much the last straw in this program and just about all I could handle with the long delays and wasted time. I could have finished the entire program by now if I only had the proper assistance that I was paying for. I cancelled the program but they would not refund anything as compensation for the time and money lost due to their inefficient program.
They have a 15 day money-back guarantee which is a joke. You would never find these problems in 15 days. You would have to experience the program and realize the inefficencies and problems later as time went on and you go further into the course materials.
I only hope that this review can help others to make a proper decision when looking for on-line training programs such as these BEFORE spending their hard earned money on it.
I would not recommend this program for all of the above reasons.
Course content is confusing; assistance takes too long plus inability or unwillingness to help out students in a timely fashion and sometimes not at all. The Career Foundry program gets a 2 on a scale of 1-10. That’s my rating for this program.

I had a terrible experience with their full stack web development program. There are much better programs out there that are more up to date on their materials and are less expensive. It seems like the only program of theirs that they care about maintaining and supporting is the UX program, but the coding program was unacceptable. Tutors that are either unavailable, don't care, or dont know how to explain coding, projects that are so out of date that all of them have broken within a few months of completing the program, and a program that makes you jump through absolutely ridiculous hoops to try to get a refund, which it doesnt seem like ever happens. This program was advertised to be able to complete in 8 months part-time, which is IMPOSSIBLE unless you have a very very low workload or job that doesnt require a lot from you. They also advertised that they have great tutors and mentor who support you throughout the program....I had 5 differrnt tutors and 3 mentors due to the absolute lack of support from previous ones, and some of them being rude and insulting when you ask for help. This program talks the talk with how supportive and amazing it is, but absolutely does not walk the walk. And the fact that their projects are YEARS out of date is ridiculous. I wish I didn't spend thousands of dollars on this program, as well as be forced to pay $500 per month for extensions due to tutors being unavailable to help, projects being obscenely put of date, and it being near impossible to complete it in the given time frame. Don't waste your time or money!!

I highly regret spending my money here.
The Web Dev course is outdated and the support is appalling. The tutor support is non-existent, you're better off paying $10 for a React course elsewhere and you'll get better help too.

Absolutely awful course. Don't believe all the reviews. It seems very suspicious there have been so many good reviews written in the last few weeks on the back of some very poor reviews. (note especially the number of reviews that were written on January 28th!) It seems highly improbable that so many members of the general public would have coincidentally written good reviews on the same day, especially when no positive reviews have been published for such a long time. Just saying...
The course is VERY outdated. There are long pieces of text to read (sadly hardly any video's - come on Careerfoundry - it's 2022!) The long, rambling texts have been translated poorly and incomprehensibly from German. Good luck if you are an English speaker.
The allocated times for tasks are ridiculous. To give an indication, they say certain tasks will take 6 hours - they will in fact will take 35 hours minimum.
It's a two year course condensed poorly into 9 months. When inevitably you don't finish in time, you get charged a monthly fee for going over the allocated time. It's a complete money making enterprise. Be prepared to shell out a lot more money than the initial course fee.
There are much, much better and far cheaper courses out there. 
I have started two other courses (I'm not sure if `i can mention the names on trustpilot) but both courses were a fraction of the price and I have already learnt more more in 2 months than I did in 12 months of Careerfoundry. 
Save yourself some money and some pain and avoid. Please also check out the negative reviews on Google. Start with the lowest reviews first. If I can save one person from the wasted year I have been through it would be worth it. I would give no stars if I could.

Although the course is super intense and demanding (and I honestly mean it), I consider it one of the best educational choices I have made. I tried some other UX courses in the past; however, they all missed one thing: STRUCTURE. 
The amount of support you receive in order to succeed is enormous, and I am saying this as a newbie in the field. I appreciate the information and the instructions delivered and the proficiency and friendliness of my tutor, mentor, and the entire CF community. I can honestly recommend it to anybody who wishes to change his professional path.

Terrible experiences German service and Tutors terrible you can find better help in youtube fro free than the help the tutors here give the students terrible tutors not willing to help you complete the task they are very good in the enrolment stage but after you are enrolled you are just a number there nobody at CF will help you don't waste your time here

I have been so extremely grateful for the team at CareerFoundry! My tutor Rachel is so kind and helpful with her feedback (and always timely!). My mentor Sam has been so encouraging, I really appreciate his feedback on my achievements (the bigger portions of the project that he reviews). I would highly recommend CareerFoundry to anyone who needs the flexibility of online learning and is unable to attend live discussions. They have a HUGE slack community that is always at the ready to connect and offer support as well. The student services team has been very easy to communicate with about my timeline concerns when I had a family emergency. 
Overall, I am very happy thus far. I can't wait to finish and go through the job preparation section of the program. I have a good feeling that it will not disappoint.

Coming into the tech world form a non-tech background was an intimidating notion. Learning new tools, terminologies, and technologies was a tall order! After 6 months with CareerFoundry I can now speak fluently in the language of UX and have designed an app from the ground up to the point of developer handoff. I could not have achieved this without the support and encouragement of my tutor, mentor, and advisers here. I'm not out of the weeds yet, but now that I'm finished with my immersion course and focusing on CareerFoundry's job prep course, I am fully confident that I'll be up and running with a new job in no time!

Hey! I think that sometimes the course could be more practical, with more videos showing how to use some of the tools instead.
The instructors are very nice, their feedback is always helpful in many ways.
And even if the job assistance is good, it could be improved by having more direct contact with the supplier's support team to avoid any miscommunication.

As a student with no background in web development & coding in general, I feel CareerFoundry is the best choice I ever made. The curriculum is very well organised, I was skeptical at first when I knew it was online but when I started the course I felt involved in the course more than ever, there's so much to learn and to practice that you don't feel the time pass by and you just want to finish one task and start another.  
My tutor and mentor are people who you look up to they are always there to help, give advices and guide me through my coding journey. 
The Student advisors are very welcoming and they always keep contact through encouraging emails. 
I encourage anyone who is interested in coding to take Full-Stack Web development course at CareerFoundry you won't regret it!

I am currently taking the full stack web development course at CareerFoundry. It has been very challenging, but also exciting, as I gradually figure out how everything works, having come into this with almost no coding experience. My mentor at CareerFoundry has been very supportive, encouraging, and helpful.

I took the monthlong Career Foundry bootcamp to dip my toes into HTM and CSS (I'm learning how to build websites), and it was excellent. From the content to UX to mentorship, I was highly impressed and learned a ton. The pacing was great and the feedback and assistance I got when I needed help blew me away. I would absolutely recommend and take again!

I'm finishing my UX course at CareerFoundry and it definitely worth its money and all the effort. They built the whole journey based on the experience of the potential students. Starting with the articles in the blog, when you're in the wondering phase of what to do and which way to go; to tutor and mentor, who are very helpful and motivating; to curriculum, which is written in very friendly and comprehensible language; to the vast community from all over the world; to own paced studying; to the Job guarantee option, where if you don't find a job in 6 months after the end of the course they will refund you the money. What else you would need?

I'm still not done my course yet but so far it has been great! I was on the fence of choosing between general assembly and UofT bootcamp but eventually decided on careerfoundry and I'm happy that I did. Having an mentor and tutor to support in your journey is very motivating and there is also a slack community where you can meet other people that are also taking the course. I would highly recommend this course as it has a job guarantee and a career specialist which other bootcamps don't have.

I cannot say enough good things about CareerFoundry! The course material is relevant to today's world and work as a UX designer. They walk you through the whole design process and then some, preparing you for work after the course. Tutors and mentors are a wealth of knowledge, readily available, and are genuinely excited to help students in their learning journey. I'm so pleased I chose CF!

This is a perfect course for everybody having 0 knowledge but a lot of motivation to get started in the UX field. The course gives a lot of insights and knowledge and project-based learning lets you "get your hands dirty" and learn by doing and getting a first taste of the actual work and having an industry expert as a mentor to guide you through.

From the onboarding, I have to say that everything made sense, and they sent you material before and were able to sign up to learn more about each specific study field. I studied five months prior, but I had no structure and low confidence levels when I taught. 
It would be tough to pull this off, especially with no help or direction in my portfolio. I think CareerFoundry has an excellent structure for self-paced learners who thrive on being self-accountable and dependable. Because you are in an online cohort and not in person, it is super important to build that relationship with your tutor/tutors. I had Bryce and Vijit, and they always give good feedback and send links to relevant material. Besides that, my mentor Oz is very personable and has a remarkable ability to break down problems or questions for me, and his video feedback is priceless. 
Lastly, I have just recently started working with my Career Specialist Cheron, and she is excellent and has an insightful view on why I want to pursue specific opportunities. I would say you get what you put into the program.

This course begins with a 4 week intro course as an intro to analytics, then dives into a 55-task immersion course. I am closing in on the halfway mark, and have been very impressed so far. The lessons are broken into manageable pieces and I feel very competent in each subject once I finish a section. I am nearing the end of the Tableau work (10 exercises) and I feel confident I could make a Tableau dashboard in a professional environment. My mentor and tutor provided have also been great and been readily available for any questions, whether that be the course material or the industry of data analytics itself. Overall, I was very nervous to do a bootcamp as it is completely uncharted territory for me and CareerFoundry has made me confident in my decision.

CF is extremely unprofessional in the payment issues, I cannot say about the contents because they gave me troubles even before having my first class. They are not serious, really. I haven't started the course yet and for their "mistake" I already paid 1420 euros without even having started the course. I relied on their word that they had fixed my payment schedule, while today they charged me again automatically, as if I had started already the course last September, while it's not. Remember: if you have an issue, they will be your worst nightmare. That's a pity, I was really excited to start. For sure there are much more serious and professional schools out there. Be careful how to spend your money, career changers.

Don't waste your time If you want to do UX/UI Design course here. CF Doesn't have any connections with any companies. If you want to do internships this certification is not at all eligible. Please start your career in a university or any other highly recognised education centre. All the best

It is certainly one of the best online schools that I have worked with. Great material and good organisation to work with.
Mo,

Programm ist inhaltlich ok, alles halt sehr oberflächlich, vieles unbrauchbar, aber der kursaufbau gut. 
Bei der Umsetzung, naja in meinem Fall eine tutorin, die selbst gerade in Ausbildung, teilweise selbst kein Wissen der zu nutzenden tools und Aufgaben. 
Der Mentor hat seine Bestimmung komplett verfehlt. Seine Aufgabe wäre es, Studenten mental auf das Berufsleben vorzubereiten, er demotivierte, machte mich klein und zeigte mir lediglich, dass ich nicht gut bin in dem was ich tue, das tat er aber sehr ausdauernd. Er ist selbst erst 5 Monate in dem Beruf tätig und ist seit dem Abschluss bei CF eben mentor dort.
Der Karrierespezialist, auch keine Erfahrung in der Branche, gab sich große Mühe aber wusste auch nicht wirklich, worüber wir reden sollten oder wo er mich hinführen sollte. Er war auch nicht motiviert, sich mal von sich aus bei mir zu melden, einfach mal fragen wie es mir geht nach 20, 30, 50, 70 Absagen.... generell gibt CF IMMER dem Studenten die Schuld. Es liegt am Lebenslauf, am portfolio, an der Motivation, an den Farben, der Ästhetik, der Zahl der Bewerbungen, Kritikfähigkeit, Formulierungen, Nase, whatever, Schuld ist der Student. Wenn er keinen job kriegt, macht er was falsch. 
CF vermittelt auch keine Jobs, die haben keine Kontakte in die Industrie. Null. 
Der Abschluss ist in der Industrie nicht sonderlich anerkannt, "so ne Maßnahme vom Amt halt"... 
Da macht es keinen Unterschied, da kann sich der absolvent auf den Kopf stellen, einen job kriegt er jedenfalls nicht. Ausgeschlossen. Außer natürlich man hat schon Erfahrung als Grafikdesigner, o. Ä., diese Leute werden einem immer als "Maßstab unter die Nase gehalten. 
Alles in allem, ich würde es kein zweites mal machen. Ich bin inzwischen nach 100 Bewerbungen überzeugt, das ist kein erstrebenswerter Beruf, was man so hört, sind UX designer nach kürzester Zeit ausgelaugt...

Great school! Great program with a mix of tasks, reads and a Mentor!
High quality content.
it was great, no frustration, good insights, but the exercises are a little bit to easy and to less

Es hat großen Spass gemacht, war sehr gut geleitet und alle waren sehr sehr freundlich und hilfreich. Sehr empfehlenswert. Weiss noch nicht wie es weiter geht, aber zum reinschnuppern in die Welt des Codings sicher ein guter Start...

Das war ganz interessante und spannende Erfahrung. Ich war skeptisch, dass ich es schaffe, nun habe ich alles rechtzeitig gemacht. Und fand das so gespannt, es macht richtig Spaß!!! Leider kann ich englisch nicht, musste alles übersetzen.

- Aufwand zeitlich passend
- Aufbau nachvollziehbar und visuell unterstützend
- tlw. Zu wenig background Infos für jemanden ohne coding Erfahrung
- nicht ganz nachvollziehbar wie genau das gelernte genutzt und eingesetzt werden kann
5 day coding challenge was fun. Interactive and easy to unterstand!
Danke euch für diese Challenge. Das war sehr effektiv für mich.
Es ist ganz deutlich und simple!!! Sehr empfehlenswert
Gutes Videomaterial, gute Balance zwischen Theorie und Praxis.

Ich habe die "5 Day Coding Challenge" absolviert. Ein toller Crashkurs, in dem man die Grundlagen von HTML, CSS und JavaScript lernt. 
Prima, um zu testen, ob eine Karriere als Softwareentwickler in Betracht kommt!

Congratulations!
You have completed Day 4, see you back tomorrow for Day 5.
I received this message after the 4th day of the course, but the "next" button is still not available.

I recently completed the Full Stack Development course with Code Institute, and it has been a truly transformative experience. The course provided me with in-depth knowledge and hands-on experience in software development, from HTML and CSS to the latest frameworks and technologies.
One of the standout aspects of Code Institute is the exceptional learning content and materials, which were comprehensive and well-structured. The support from the community was incredible; whenever I faced an issue, there was always someone ready to help.
Beyond the technical skills, I gained a network of amazing people from different countries, all with the same goal of mastering full-stack development. A special shout-out to the supportive team, especially Ion, who was always there to assist.
I highly recommend Code Institute to anyone looking to dive into software development. It’s not just a course but a community that supports you every step of the way.
Thank you, Code Institute, for this incredible journey!

After a long time of trying to fix bugs whilst creating more, self doubt blood sweat and tears (it wasn't that dramatic actually). I feel Code Institute has provided me with a strong foundation of skills to manage to land a job in tech, Hackathons were and still are a great boost of confidence and knowledge.

Best Software Development course I've attended by far! Content, assignments and projects were a great learning experience and the support by the Code Institute's mentors and tutors were second to none!

Enrolling in the Level 5 Double-Stack Software Development course at Code Institute of Dublin has been an incredibly rewarding experience since I joined in February. Although the program is primarily online, it truly excels at fostering connections with fellow students, tutors, mentors, and the supportive school staff.
The weekly class meetings with our dedicated teacher are an excellent feature—they're not only well-organized but also backed by opportunities for one-to-one sessions and communication through chat or email. This personal touch ensures students feel heard and supported throughout their learning journey.
Adding to this, the school hosts weekly webinars featuring tutors, alumni, entrepreneurs, and even the occasional recruiter. These sessions offer invaluable insights and inspiration from industry experts. Furthermore, while practical sessions on Agile principles are not part of the curriculum (there is a section in the learning material, though), there’s a fantastic alternative—monthly Hackathons. These are skillfully organized with teams comprising students and alumni of various skill levels, providing a brilliant opportunity to put Agile methodologies into practice. I recently participated in my first Hackathon, and I’m still buzzing with excitement from the experience!
One of the standout features is the careers team. They go above and beyond to coach students on perfecting worksearch essentials such as LinkedIn profiles and portfolios, while also offering personalized advice to help us stand out in the job market.
The learning interface is both comprehensive and challenging, striking the perfect balance to keep students engaged and motivated. In addition to the above, the school boasts a wide array of other enriching features that would take pages to list—but trust me when I say they enhance the experience remarkably.
In conclusion, Code Institute of Dublin offers an outstanding and immersive learning environment, even in an online setting. I wholeheartedly recommend this program to anyone looking to dive into software development.

I had a great expirience with the course.
Self paced, well constructed lessons.
Tutor and student support, mentoring, and community are absolutely amazing.

I am enjoying the challenge of learning a new skill. Web development and coding are skills that I have wanted to become familiar with and understand for a while and I think Code Institute delivers their web development course in an accessible way with lots of practical, hands on exercises, milestone projects and access to mentors. I feel as though I am definitely being pushed, yet learning as well. I would certainly recommend the course for anyone serious about wanting to learn web development.

Not only do they have amazing courses that really challenge and lift your skills, but the community is unrivalled. The staff are all extremely passionate about the courses and hackathons they provide and there is always support from somewhere within the institute, even long after graduating.

I had an incredible experience on the government-funded 16 week Full Stack Development for the AI Augmented Developer Bootcamp by Code Institute! While the program was high-intensity, for me personally it was also really enjoyable, keeping me engaged and constantly learning. The structured curriculum on the LMS platform and expert guidance form our cohort facilitator, our bootcamp coding coaches and our subject matter experts made a real impact on my growth. 
Not only that, a standout feature is their Slack community and the sheer variety of information channels they offer, which makes remote learning feel truly interactive and engaging. Being part of a vibrant, contributing network of students (past and present) and staff has been amazing for learning, collaboration, and support throughout my journey.
 Yes, it’s hard (it’s a lot of information to process in a short timespan), and it’s not for everyone, but if you’re like me and you thrive on challenging and really pushing yourself to  go further in your understanding, and don’t let challenges stop you, then this course could be for you. 
One of the standout aspects is the monthly hackathons, which provide an amazing opportunity to refine skills, build confidence, make valuable connections and apply what you’ve learned in a fun (and competitive!) way. Winning first place in the April 2025 Unmask the Coder: Beating Impostor Syndrome One Line at a Time hackathon with my team was a huge highlight for me! It was certainly an apt theme for my first true hackathon and with one being held each month hopefully it won’t be my last! 
Beyond the technical training however, Code Institute also offers career support and guidance, including 1:1 sessions, an LMS Careers course tailored to job readiness, webinars featuring insights from past alumni and major tech employers, and also hold an insightful annual Elevate careers fair that is a wealth of information and tips for a anyone wanting a career in tech.
These resources have been invaluable in preparing me for the job market and building connections in the industry. 
Overall, I highly recommend Code Institute to anyone looking to gain hands-on experience in software development. The support, learning environment, and continuous skill-building opportunities make it an exceptional choice for anyone passionate about growing in this field! It’s not surprising that they received an Outstanding rating from Ofsted this year!
Excelente, from the perspective of some one who has finished the program and get the job even before that, great team and support Code Institute

I decided during the summer of 2024 that I wanted, needed a career change. Tech has always been a huge interest of mine, so I began searching for options to study software development. 
That's when I found the Full Stack Diploma in Software Development with The Code Institute. I began my course in November 2024, and I've never looked back. amazing. 
The focus is not just on the learning content (material, challenges) you also learn about the tech industry. I also have a career program running alongside my diploma to get me career-ready, for potential employers when the time comes. 
There are also amazing events in the Events Hub - where you can get actual potential employer insights from companies, recruitment, live tutor sessions on topics, and of course, alumni who have completed their journey.
I have a 1:1 mentor who is actively working in the industry to help me with my milestone projects, and there are other supports available. BIG shout out to the Code Institute Slack Community.
Code Institute is an Ofsted Outstanding Provider, and you can really see why when you're within the community. I have no regrets, I am halfway through plenty of ups and downs, but it is so rewarding.
What an experience for a first Hackathon, I would recommend anyone to join in and be a part of this amazing event.
The hackathon idea at Code Institute is amazing! I enjoy teaming up with new members every month to create exciting projects that also help strengthen my portfolio.
Just finished the 5 coding challenge, it’s a great introduction, finally I can at least know what exactly I should learn and how.  A little challenging but interesting at the same time.
It gave me an idea of what coding was all about, and now I am more informed. Thank you
The course y Relevant,  intuitive and easy.
The course was pretty informative and I was able to go through it pretty easily. However I did not get a completion certificate for the course.
I loved how we could practice alongside learning and that lessons were scheduled no live classes making it easy for anyone to make time and learn irrespective of timezones.

I believe this Challenge offers a great introduction to the world of coding—it gives you a quick and accessible way to explore whether this path is right for you.
However, during the phone call, I felt that there wasn’t enough attention paid to my personal background, my motivation for pursuing this career, or whether I had any specific questions. It would really make a difference if these conversations felt more personalized and human. Taking the time to understand each person’s story and goals could help build a stronger connection and make the experience much more meaningful.

I completed the Full Stack Software Development diploma in November and specialised in Predictive Analytics. Everyday that passes I feel like I completely wasted my time and almost €8,000 doing this course. The projects are worthless and employers don’t care about them. This course desperately needs a work a placement of some sort. I wasted a full year doing this course, working full time and trying to do well. I’ve applied for hundreds of jobs and follow up on every lead possible. Predictive Analytics needs to be scrapped, it’s awful and NO TUTOR SUPPORT?!?!? That is mind boggling. The one positive is that the Student Care team are great, especially Kim. There’s just no hope getting a job with this diploma alone which completely defeats the purpose of it in my opinion. The content seems to be just rehashed and reused from previous years. I feel disheartened to be completely honest and I’ve pretty much given up on my ideal job of Software Developer and decided to pursue promotions in my current job. What a waste of time and money.

I tried the 5 Day Coding Challenge to get a taste for web development and help me to decide if it would be a good career path for me. The Learning Management System is great and the teaching style is very clear and effective, which made the whole experience satisfying and enthusing. I got a great insight into the world of web development and it was fantastic to get some hands on experience as opposed to just reading/watching content. I would 100% recommend taking the challenge if you're curious about this field, as it's a relatively quick way to get a good idea of what it entails, and the delivery of the challenge is superb.

As a beginner this was extremely hard to complete. Even with the slowest plan you have 12 months and the hours/week they say you’ll need that should be at least doubled if not tripled.. Too much information and definitely not enough time to understand and keep up as a complete beginner. There was no such thing as career advice afterwards. Once exams were done i never heard of them again except for a phone call i received more than a year after completing the course asking me if i found a job in the field. Well i didn’t. And after paying all that money they cut your access to the learning material once the last exam is submitted. I did learn a lot but overall this was a huge disappointment.. Many things are being promised and those promises are not kept. I don’t think it’s worth the money and i definitely don’t think that things that are not going to happen should be promised..

I believe there are areas in which this company can improve such as the structure of the course. I'm not sure the qualifications they offer are significant enough to gain meaningful employment in industry for most people, as you'll be competing with many individuals that are significantly more qualified. 
I don't think the Diploma in Full Stack Software Development justifies the price tag they are charging, just my two cents.

Just took part in my first ever hackathon, and what an experience it was! This month’s theme was CodeHer: Women in Tech, run by Code Institute – and it was genuinely brilliant. All the teams brought their A-game, with loads of creativity and some seriously impressive projects on show.
Best bit? My team came 3rd place! Not too shabby for a first go, if I do say so myself.
I also made some great connections along the way – it was such a welcoming and inspiring community to be part of. A really enjoyable event all round – can’t wait for the next one

I did the 6-week AI-Augmented Full-Stack Bootcamp course. The remote and self-paced nature of the course worked well for me. We covered everything from HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, Agile Project Management, DBMS, JavaScript, Python Django and Git...everything you need to build a full-stack web app. The course material provided enough foundation for us to explore further and self-learn after the course. The course included two individual projects and two hackathons, which were challenging but we learnt so much through them.
The tutors were incredibly helpful, and went above and beyond to ensure all of us got a good grounding in the diverse range of topics. We were in a cohort of about twenty students, and we got to know each other and supported each other through the daily standups and groupwork. We continue to support each other through job-search and exploring other learning beyond the course.
Code Institute also provides incredible support after the course through the careers support, 1-2-1 coaching, recruiter webinars, etc. The Careers Hub was a source of great tips for setting up my CV and LinkedIn, effective job search and interview skills.
The CI community includes all students from the various courses across the UK and Europe. I have just taken part in the monthly cross-community hackathon, where students can meet other coders at various stages of their course and alumni who can share their expertise and experience. We had a tough brief but it was great fun learning new things. I can't wait to show off my hackathon badge on LinkedIn.
On the whole, my learning experience has been intensive but life-changing...thoroughly enjoyable and definitely worthwhile.

Code Institute's hackathons (all three of them I've done so far) have been extremely valuable to me in terms of learning to become fluent in the technologies I've been trained in (and in other technologies that are new to me).
I've also learnt a lot about working under time pressure in a small collaborative team, with all the coordination and diplomacy that requires.
On top of that, I have made some very interesting connections that I hope will be both pleasant and useful in the future.
Lastly, I genuinely had a ball!

It's a good intro into web development but i feel like the content was being reused from previous years, some of the video tutorials looked like they were from a previous versipn of the code space. And yes it helps to nurse people by telling em exactly what to do in the challenges, they could of have left it up to us to figure out how to achieve the goal with the option of taking hints. It just felt like I was being told what to write without me using my brain at all, how am I suppose to learn like that??
I enjoyed this. It was easier than I expected, but if you want to know if you're even remotely likely to succeed as a software developer, the five day coding challenge is worth doing.

The Level 3: Very poorly organised nothingness. It won't help you get a job and there is little too no support. Do NOT pay for this course, we had a change of lecturer at the end of the course, I have now been on the course for 1 year and 3 months, it was meant to be a 6 month course, no sign of a certificate. I did well in all of the units and passed everything first time and even helped other students with some issues they had. Really poor course delivered by Runshaw.

My learning experience at Code Institute has been outstanding. The structured curriculum, hands-on projects, and excellent mentorship made the learning process both engaging and effective. The platform is well-organized, and the support from tutors and the student community helped me stay motivated throughout the course. I particularly appreciated the real-world applications of the projects, which helped me build a strong portfolio. The career support team also provided valuable guidance for job preparation, making the transition into the tech industry much smoother.
However, I would love to see Code Institute expand its learning support in the future to include additional programming languages such as C++ and other low-level languages. Adding courses focused on low-level programming, embedded systems, and system-level development would be a great enhancement for those interested in a broader range of technical fields.

Starting the last project at Code Institute has been an amazing capstone of my journey in full-stack software development. I have really honed my technical expertise by working extensively with HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, and Python and have been able to produce solutions that amaze me every time. Every line of code has been an opportunity to learn, grow, and deliver something useful.
Bittersweet it is to part with a fantastic community, but I know we will carry this forward. Every challenge I have faced and every lesson learned has indeed prepared me for the next chapter as a confident and capable software developer.

I recently graduated with my diploma in Full-Stack Software Development, and I am incredibly grateful to the Code Institute.
Initially, I was skeptical about the program being 100% remote. However, after completing the five-day coding challenge, I decided to take the plunge and fully commit to this opportunity.
The first modules were relatively straightforward, but they became progressively more challenging quite quickly. Fortunately, the support network, along with the entire Slack community, is incredible and very supportive. Whenever I faced challenges, I could always count on another student who had gone through similar issues and had great solutions to share.
Each student is assigned a mentor to assist with projects, which proved extremely useful since all learning is done independently. It felt like having a guardian angel during tough times. Additionally, a tutor support team is available throughout the day to help with any bugs or problems students may encounter.
The Slack community also tirelessly organizes events, webinars, and video calls to prepare students for the tech industry. Top recruiters host live sessions, and there is a dedicated careers team that works closely with students to help them secure their first tech role, offering one-on-one support.
What mattered most to me was that I never felt alone during my coding journey. Even though I graduated over a month ago, I am still actively involved in the Slack community.
This diploma is excellent, and I highly recommend the Code Institute to anyone with a passion for technology, IT, or development!
Big thanks to the Code Institute team, mentors, tutors, assessors, and career coaches for making this journey smooth and beginner-friendly.

I loved the 5 Day Coding Challenge!
I already had some experience in programming, but I was able to refresh and also learn a lot.
I wouldn't have done all the challenges if code institute hadn't extended my access, so thanks.
In my opinion, there could have been more space for the leaner to explore and experiment, e.g. by not saying directly which tag to use but a tag for a paragraph et cetera.
Furthermore, JavaScript has also been somewhat shortened. I would have loved working with it in an additional task.
Altogether a great experience that makes you want to discover the world of programming.

I can absolutely recommend the Code Institute for anyone who is thinking about studying for a diploma in software programming. 
I had zero coding experience before the course so it was very challenging. But the course is well-structured and the material is clearly explained; I particularly appreciated the walk-through tasks that set you up for your main projects.
If you take this course you'll need to devote a fair bit of time and energy to it, but it's 100% worth it.
I took part in the 5 day coding challenge and found it very informative and enjoyable and a great introduction to HTML, CSS, JavaScript and website design.

I took the level 5 diploma in web application development. The structure of the course it great to follow - If, like me, you can get a bit bogged down with reading a lot of text they also have playgrounds where you can practice the code and see how it all connects and works visually as well as challenges that keep testing your knowledge to make sure it sinks in. 
The support is incredible. You will be assigned a mentor who will go through your main projects with you, they are also open to slack messages but you also have a tutor support team, a community with thousands of people and a cohort helping you through the course so you will always find someone who can help or pier review your work.
The hackathons each months are also a great way to collaborate, meet new people and get some experience working in an agile environment.
Couldn't recommend Code Institute enough - a great place to start your career in development
The 5 day challenge was very fun, I had never coded before so this was a quick look to see if I would like it and I loved it. The course is very informative and well structured.

A good course with a good culture
FYI code institute have multiple courses now, I did remote 5 project with advanced frontend
a quick overview of pros and area to improve:
pros:
- Wonderful hackathon idea for students and alumni. It is quite hard to find friendly hackathons in the general public on platforms like Devpost
- project-orientated approach was good
- supportive slack community with regular online events 
- the general culture is positive, professional and inclusive. Special shout out to the community engagement leads for being available to answer Questions and support students
- tutor support team were ever so helpful, I did my homework before approaching them and I could rely on tutors to help me along with junior-level bugs and get over the finish line
- this kind of part time/ remote/ 12 months is a far more effective approach to career changing than 12 week bootcamps. 
- the course regularly listen to student's feedback and do their best to adapt
areas to improve:
-  I have finished this course with more reservations about the overall value of follow-along video tutorials.  I found them helpful in moderation, especially at the beginning, but by the time I reached project 5 specialisation advanced frontend module it felt overkill and could have done without 70% of it in the grand scheme of things - by this point I knew how to set up a project and use Node Package Manager. This is quite a difficult balance to get right to be fair, as all learners are different. For context, CI do not make video tutorials compulsory and provide alot of support for meeting project deadlines on time.
- considering AWS is the largest share of cloud services worldwide it would be nice to include more of their free tier. The curriculum I took did not include AWS.
- I would have traded project mentoring for more career support mentoring sessions personally. For context CI offer 1 halfway through the course and I believe there is support for when you secure an interview.
I still maintain a positive relationship with this course and look forward to attending more hackathons!
I aim to update this review once I have landed my first full-time job in the Tech industry.

Just about to hand in my 4th and final Project. Didn’t know a line of HTML a year ago and I’m submitting a fully working e-commerce site with AWS hosting and payment processing. 
Sometimes two steps forward and one step backwards. Yes, some of the content is out of date and has caused delays or problems - but hey, that’s how the real world works. Whatever problem you hit, someone on YouTube or stack overflow has also hit it before. 
My mentor was superb. Just enough guidance and pointing in the right direction with no hand holding. 
Only used the tutor support on a couple of issues but they delivered. They can be brusque as they are very busy.  
I generally tried to sort problems myself as that’s where a lot of the learning takes place, so could be a bit of a rollercoaster - but that’s why I like software development. It works or it doesn’t and when it does it’s amazing feedback. 
Although some online content could do with updating, it’s comprehensive and well structured. The walkthroughs at the end of each project are particularly instructive. 
There’s a lot of free content on the web but it’s difficult to sort the good from the bad if your knowledge of the subject is limited. I can’t imagine my comprehension of the subject matter would be where it is if I’d relied on YouTube alone - and I would have picked up a lot of bad habits and inaccurate advice along the way. 
If you want to sit back and be spoonfed the content and given all the answers then this isn’t the course for you. But then, neither is a career in software development.

The way the challenge content is organized is very enjoyable and consistent. So I had finished it with a good mood/feeling.  Your daily follow up and encouragement is also helping to accomplish the challenge. Thank you very much!

As someone who did some programming in the past, I was positively surprised about the progress. The first day was super basic, but they managed to include quite some nice tricks over the next days. 
You cannot *do* much with that knowledge, but I think it's a good little trip to understand the way of thinking and If you enjoy this or not. (HTML and CSS give amazing instant gratification and motivate to experiment - reality is much more lengthy, unfortunately) But yes, I enjoyed it a lot.
It was a great experience! Thanks for the opportunity 🙏🏻

Enrolling in Code Institute’s Full Stack Software Developer Diploma course was one of the best decisions I’ve ever made. As a newcomer to coding, I’ve learned an incredible amount in a structured and supportive environment. 
The curriculum is designed with a hands-on approach, allowing me to apply what I learn through practical projects, which has greatly accelerated my understanding. The combination of well-structured modules, interactive challenges, and a strong support network makes this program an excellent choice for anyone looking to break into software development. Highly recommended!
Hackathon is an excellent experience to boost skills and Confidence

It would be better, to make sure that the people who decided to join the Hakathon working and putting some effort with the group they joined, unfortunately , the last group i joined, only two team member were working out of six.
It would be better if the organizers choose the Scrum master according to his qualification and experience, the last Hakathon i joined, the scrum master has  just disappeared before submission.

The hackathon was very well organised and people in my group were super supportive - as it was my first hackathon experience, I found it a bit challenging but everyone was really kind, encouraging, and understanding.
The content was delivered in small enough chunks to be challenging and also doable each day.

I recently completed the Full Stack Software Developer diploma with Code Institute, and I would not hesitate to recommend this for anybody whether you're already experienced with software development, or like me are brand new to the industry! The course content was very clear to follow, and the support offered by the tutor team, mentors and your fellow students via slack was amazing. I'm also a neurodivergent student, and Code Institute were beyond incredible in supporting me when my disability caused me to struggle. I'm honestly so happy I chose this course to start my journey as a Developer!
It's good experience for anyone looking to strengthen coding skills. Get a nice badge for LinkedIn. Also get to connect with other coders and wider your network.

I recently took part in a Love.exe themed hackathon last week for a few days. It was great fun and great to get real world experience working in a team! It is great that Code Institute put on hackathons every month!
it was great, no frustration, good insights, but the exercises are a little bit to easy and to less

Code Institute Review: Outdated, Overpriced, and Useless 
If you’re considering Code Institute, don’t waste your time or money. My experience with this program was one of the biggest disappointments of my life. The course is outdated, the support is terrible, and the diploma is useless when it comes to finding a job.
Outdated Material That Causes More Problems Than It Solves
The course material is years old, using outdated technologies and versions that no longer work with current models. This leads to endless issues where code doesn’t function as expected, and I was left confused, wasting hours trying to figure out problems caused by obsolete lessons. Instead of updating their content, Code Institute continues to sell a broken program that sets students up for failure.
Little to No Real Support
When I encountered issues (which was often due to the outdated content), I turned to tutoring sessions for help—only to be met with rude and unhelpful tutors. Some of them couldn’t even fix the problems themselves, wasting my entire session before telling me to wait another week for new tutoring hours to reset. How is a beginner supposed to solve problems if even the tutors don’t have answers?
Mentorship was no better. My mentor’s advice? Compare my code to his old project from three years ago, even though our projects had nothing in common. When he still couldn’t figure out why my code wasn’t working, I was forced to delete everything and start over, with no explanation of what went wrong.
A Rigged Assessment Process That Forces You to Pay More
The way Code Institute runs its assessments feels intentionally designed to make students fail so they have to pay for resets also if you don’t agree with the results well to bad because you can’t contest it. They market themselves as a job-ready coding bootcamp, but the reality is that the course doesn’t prepare you for real-world work at all. When I finished, I realized that I still didn’t have the skills needed to land a job.
Code Institute Cares About Money, Not Students
This company is profit-driven, not education-focused. They prioritize making money over actually helping students succeed. I wouldn’t trust them as my experience was nothing as it was advertised to me. 
Final Verdict: Don’t Fall for the Hype
If you value your time, money, and mental health, avoid Code Institute at all costs. There are much better learning options out there with fairer assessments, better support, and up-to-date material. This program was a massive waste of money, and I strongly advise others to look elsewhere.
I'm a university graduate in Cameroon and I'm here in Germany for three years. I did Praktikum in taking care of cows and Austrich in Germany Prenzlau 5 montha

My sincere recommendation is to NEVER buy this course! The videos were recorded many years ago with irrelevant information and using old versions of libraries, which only creates a lot of problems.  The material on the platform is hard to understand. Slack with thousands of channels is just a waste of time. And if you want to get help from technical mentors, you always have to answer a few questions to a chatbot. And if the answer is not comprehensive, you will be denied help. Sessions with a mentor are absolutely useless, because they don't help you with your code, they just tell you to Google it. On the platform, important information is presented in gray text, which is difficult to read. So it's better to use another course, because this one doesn't really aim to give you knowledge, but only to rip you off and not do their part in return.

My experience at the Code Institute was unbeatable. The course is very demanding but you can progress through the course at your own pace as long as you meet the project deadlines. At the end of the course you leave with 5 projects ready to put in your portfolio and show your work to recruiters and future employers. You also have to work well on the projects as they are personal (not in a team) and this forces you to focus and move forward even though you have the help of the Slack community, mentors and tutor. Something unique and interesting about the Code Institute is the possibility to participate in hackathons and meet new people in the projects you have to work on for 5 days and practice working in a group with tools like Github or using Agile. The possibility of doing a specialisation is something that I really enjoyed because it allowed me to develop my final project in an area in which I wanted to develop my skills more and go deeper in this area.
Very wrong, too basic and rude staff

It’s good for teaching you WHAT you should learn for the most part but terrible at actually teaching you the subjects. Video based learning but the videos are very basic and lack most information. Also, student support are useless and can take days to get back to you so if you are on a tight timescale with a project and need assistance you are basically doomed. Your mentors aren’t allowed to mentor you, only guide. They can’t tell you how to do things so you can’t actually get any help from a human being. You have to google anything you need help with. I regret forking out the 7.5k for this course along with some of my fellow students who all feel the same way. It’s fine if you live in Ireland and can do the course for free but DO NOT pay for it. I spent £30 on a course focused on css and learnt much more in those 4 days then I did after 3 months learning through Code Institute.

It was okay. I did the full 16 week course. Not just the 5 day course that others have mentioned. 
I managed to get on the course for free as a job seeker, and I'm glad I did as if I had paid for it I would have been very disappointed. 
The HTML and CSS modules were a really good, comprehensive and easy to understand teaching method. So when I first started it had high hopes that I would do really well on the course. However, when JavaScript was introduced it was a different story. I found it quite difficult to learn and for some reason the way they taught it differed greatly from the HTML and CSS sections. 
The videos and questions were a bit all over the place. There were times when they would tell you to go and look at a previous chapter to remind yourself, but the resources weren't there. Then they would crop up again later on in later chapters. It was like they took a year long course and shaved it down to a 16 week course. 
Once you got your head around the basics of JavaScript you were thrust head long into Python. Likewise again the teaching was really poor and frustrating. I think we ended up doing 2 weeks on python, and then onto Django for our final project. 
I understand that there is limited time, but I feel it just wasn't enough time to learn even the basics of what was required. 
Very little support from the mentors. My mentor was very likeable, but I felt she lacked knowledge and we were often told she would "look into it" and never got back to you. You were constantly told to go and use outside free resources for answers to questions. This is my issue with the course. You can find everything the course offers on the internet for free. In my case watching YouTube was more enlightening than anything the tutors taught us. The sessions with the experts were watching them make something, which was not only boring but didn't teach us anything.
