There were some very good bits, however. The careers advice was pretty good, and for someone like me who has very little experience applying for jobs this was a really good part of the course. I now feel more confident in the jobs market, even if I have decided that the tech world is not my calling. 
Coming out of the course it became pretty clear that the tech jobs are none existent in my area of the country, and a lot were based in London and Newcastle (I don't live near either). 
I also would have preferred it if the careers advice was a bit more generic, as a lot was about how to get a tech job, something I am clearly not going to get. 
Overall I'm pleased I completed it, but I didn't learn anything I couldn't have probably accessed for free ether on the internet or in the community. 
Please save your money, and if you are offered a place for free then take it, but don't expect miracles and 3 months later I am still unemployed, but at least I've had a few interview where I've been close to securing a job.
Great course: progressive, well set out, good time scale, well described, helpful coach support.

Code Institute is a good learning institution, but they will NOT find you a job. The majority of students who took the Full Stack Development course have not yet found any roles, and most of the vacancies are not related to the skills taught in the course. This course might be suitable for young students just starting their careers, but I definitely would not recommend it for career changers.

Do not waste your time or money with this company. Ignore the glowing reviews, as they are likely paid or solicited. This organization is focused on making money rather than genuinely supporting students.
Their assessment process is designed to ensure you fail, forcing you to pay for resets at every opportunity. You are given a maximum of three attempts per project, and each reset requires an additional payment. With five projects in total, you could end up paying for up to 15 resets if they keep failing you for minor issues.
Even if you follow the mentors' instructions perfectly—documenting your code, providing screenshots, and conducting thorough manual and automated testing—they will still fail you. I personally had a project that worked perfectly, was documented with all the necessary evidence, and passed initial criteria. Yet, they failed it after claiming a functionality issue that clearly didn’t exist at the time of submission. They completely ignore their own teachings, leaving you powerless to defend your work.
This company thrives on taking advantage of students’ time, effort, and money. Their assessors are disconnected from what the mentors teach, and they refuse to take responsibility for issues that arise outside your control, such as code-breaking during the long wait for assessment results.
If you value your time, money, and mental health, avoid this program. There are far better options out there with fairer assessment processes and actual student support.

The 5-day coding challenge is fine but for the main course all videos are of low quality and for some of them you can not understand the subject completely and there is no one to ask. If you ask anything from them they will just say search it on Google. I don't recommend taking this course and paying £7000. put £7000 in your pocket and learn everything from Google and Youtube.

The videos recorded in 5 years ago with low quality.
If you ask anything about your project from your mentor , your mentor will say google it. 
honestly I'm regret to paid £7000.00 for this course.
my advise to you is just learn everything from Youtube and google. doesn't worth to do it.

Really enjoyed it. It's a bit frustrating that you have to submit your details every time you want to look at any course content or receive a download as this seems to generate a new enquiry every time and leads to duplication.

The course was free and accredited, exactly as advertised, and I have recieved a certificate (pdf) that has an official accreditation ref number. It offered a good introduction into coding, with fairly simple step by step guides. I personally found that to fully understand some of the lessons, I needed to attempt to repeat and modify the code in Visual Studio so I could see the effects. I recently completed a 5-day coding challenge focused on learning HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for designing webpages, and it was a great experience!
The challenge was well-paced, with each day covering different aspects of web design, starting from the basics and gradually progressing to more advanced topics. I appreciated how each day’s content built on the previous one, helping me to understand both the structure and style of webpages, as well as how to add interactivity with JavaScript.
The practical exercises were the highlight of the challenge, allowing me to apply what I learned by creating real projects. It was rewarding to see my progress from simple designs to more polished, interactive pages. The instructions were clear, and there was plenty of support throughout the process.
Overall, this 5-day challenge is a great way to get started with web design and development. It’s perfect for anyone looking to build a solid foundation in coding and start creating their own webpages.

I am specifically rating with regards to my experience on the 5 Day Coding Challenge.
At its core, the challenge is an amazing idea: it attracts people with zero coding background to try a new skill which is something they could put to use in a variety of areas. Its accessible, free, and doesn't require too much of your time, and can be completed however you see fit within the timespan of a week. 
However, I didn't feel that the course appropriately accomodated its target audience. I was lucky to have some background in the use of HTML and very very minimal CSS knowledge, which carried me through days 1-3. Other people were not so lucky. I saw many people getting immediately confused with the content and going to the Slack group for help, where they were assisted by someone who didn't even work for Code Institute. Several people mentioned using YouTube to find the answers as they felt this wasn't adequately explained through the Code Institute's videos. 
When I asked a query about the programme, it took the better part of a day for me to get a response. If this was the response time for queries regarding the actual code, then I can't say that seems very helpful, especially when you are on a rather strict timeframe of finishing everything in a week. I'm not sure how many queries were being sent, or how many members of staff there were to deal with this, but I think its clear that response time from CI's end was not great. This, coupled with videos which had typos in them and weak voiceover in some areas, made me feel that I was better off just using the written instructions which accompanied the tasks, and that's actually how I did days 4-5. 
This is not to say that I think the concept of the course is bad, and I do have positive things to say about some parts. The programme they use to tell you whether your exercises have been completed correctly was incredibly useful, and I really enjoyed the process of running my code, seeing the output, and adjusting to make something better. The idea of building up a functional website over the days was also interesting, though I felt this would have been better if the code which it carried over was yours, instead of their own code again. I just feel like the course needs a lot of TLC. I understand that, as a free course, this is probably low on the list of priorities for Code Institute. However, I will say my experience on this course would probably put me off pursuing the larger, paid-for course that CI run. 
I have heard that the course is being evaluated, and so I hope that the information I've provided in this review gives some direction as to what needs to be changed. There is such strong potential for this course to be an entry point for new coders, but right now, it just fails to be that stepping stone.

At the time of enrollment, the content was extremely outdated (no Flexbox or grid for HTML/CSS, the libraries used for the Advanced Front End project were from 3 years ago, the authentication method is not aligned with the HTTP standard -and nobody was able to explain to me how it works because the tutorial is just a code along with no real explanation of this-, and the Django tutorial was disappointing, to the point that even using the same project, the course was recently changed 100%).
When I approached tutoring, they were not able to help me most of the time, because they follow the templates on the tutorials, therefore, if the student tries to come up with something new for her/his project or even use the updated version of the libraries/frameworks, they are not able to help you.
Probably it was a matter of bad luck, that I got into the course right before the content was updated, but I paid the same amount of money as the student enrolling 3 months after me.
On the other hand, if the student has doubts about the content or wants to go deeper into a topic, there is no one to help you. In the end, there is almost nothing more than the content and being able to use the community on Slack (which IMHO is not worth thousands of Euros).
If you decide to enroll, I would advise you to stick to the tutorials as much as possible when creating the projects. Change one or two things to have a pass, and create an awesome README for merit. If you would like to probably have distinction (because the criteria are not clear) try coming up with something new but simple, and write an extremely clean code.
If you need a diploma, Code Institute is a good option. But if not, I would recommend buying Udemy courses (which are not more than €18… never pay the higher amount, there are discount codes all over the internet, just Google it). There is no other advantage; at least the Udemy courses are usually updated as soon as there is a new version of the frameworks (speaking about the Django, Javascript, and React courses I needed to buy to complete the course). If you have doubts, most of the courses give you access to a Discord server where, sometimes, even the creator of the course answers questions, no matter if they are part of the content or not.
NOTES:
1. It seems like CI is going through a change in almost everything. But, my experience was not good. I hope they manage to sort everything out, which is a lot.
2. Student Care and the facilitators (at least the one I had) are extremely supportive, but the internal politics seem to have them hands-tied in helping you have a better learning experience.

The selling point of the course for me was the weekly online tutorship through a college, however despite having staffing issues, the college accepted students but did not supply lectures for the first three months and then when they had a lecturer, the lectures typically lasted 90 minutes a week and the lecturer was unavailable at any other time to answer questions or feedback.
I'm response to this I was told that the lectures were supplementary to the online course and not their problem if we didn't have them. 
You would be much better off with Udemy or YouTube and self teaching and saving yourself the £5k and a headache from dealing with Code Institute.

The 5 day coding course taught me the basic building blocks of HTML/CSS and Javascript, and how they all fit together. The lessons were planned out very well  with each one building onto the previous, and reusing skills previously taught so that they are well reinforced in your memory.
The addition of a slack group chat for trouble shooting and encouragement was also a wonderful addition, and it personally helped me and multiple others when we got stuck. Thank you to the kind helpers in that groupchat! It was also encouraging to see how many people were on the course, and from all walks of life.
They also graciously extended the course availability to the Sunday night, so that those who had been too busy to complete some days lessons could catch up.
Overall, I really enjoyed this course, and looked forward to learning each day. I made a bunch of notes from the lessons and it has spurred me on to continue learning about web page development so that one day I can create my own nifty web page one day!

I signed up for their free 5-day coding taster course. Although the layout and tech was great, the content wasn't so much and that's because the lessons didn't cover the end-of-day tests. Day 1 was easy-peasy - the lesson was appropriate and the test tested you on what you'd learnt. Day 2 not so much: the test at the end of that day wasn't covered in the lesson and so you were encouraged to do a Google search with the narrative that "even the most experienced coders will have to use Google to solve a problem, from time to time!" But two points on that: Day 2 of an absolute beginners course is NOT an appropriate level to be expected to Google the answers, it should be covered in the lessons! And I didn't sign up for an aptitude test, I signed up to learn a bit of coding. I managed to pass the first couple of tests at the end of Day 2 with a lot of playing around to see what worked, but it was a time-wasting exercise because it should simply have been covered in the day's lesson! I saw a few comments in the Slack channel as well from people who were struggling simply because what we were being tested on hadn't been taught. I also commented the same and got a private message from someone asking me if I'd figured it out because he hadn't managed to. I became demotivated about the course after that because this messing around was not what I'd signed up for. Am I still interested in coding? Yes! But a course that teaches THE BASICS rather than testing your aptitude to Google it. I'd give it 5 stars for the tech, but 1 for the content, hence the generous 3 stars. Not my style of "teaching" I'm afraid. I don't recommend it.

I passed four projects and failed the last with only 4points. This meant I was declined points for any of the terms I have completed and told that since I didn't get those four points I don't receive any points for any of the work I have done. This meant I cannot use csn again and means that the course was a huge waste of time. In most college courses you pass a project /coursework you get some points..here it will be as if you didn't go anything at all. Don't recommend. Course material was good, and after passing 95 percents the course I benefited. But I have no points nothing to show for it. Take course at own risk if using csn.

This is a FREE 'introductory' course meant to cover the basics of learning how to write/design/and, also, add interactivity to web pages; and, as such it covered the use of: HTML(write)/CSS(design)/Javascript(interactivity).
If you are a complete 'beginner'; then, this course will have something very useful for you to learn. But, if you are of 'intermediate' level ability...; then, frankly, there's not an awful lot to learn here that's entirely 'new'.
-----
Concerning the basic HTML/CSS we learned...I already knew how to do that...; namely, how to order the 4 main tag pairs: HTML/HEAD/TITLE/BODY; and, also, how to use CSS id's/classes.
It also used Javascript to re-size text onMouseOver=""/onMouseOut=""...both of which I already knew.
I particularly enjoyed the parts which taught how to employ different 'graphics/fonts' to a web page by using Font Awesome/and, also, the use of 'responsive' web design...using @ media queries.
-----
5 days...is an extremely 'short' time period to learn any, truly, 'in-depth' stuff; but, if you were a total 'beginner'...; then, I imagine, this course is extremely effective...when it comes to getting down the 'basics', really and truly, fast.
Certainly, beginner's will -at the very least- come out of it being able to 'write/design' their own web pages for themselves.
-----
But, for people who are already used to writing their own very 'basic' web pages...; then, they will need to consider taking on doing the much more 'advanced' 16 weeks long course; which, I heard, is very 'expensive'...(unless you are eligible to obtain further funding/or else, can 'afford' it).

I'm absolutely new to this but I struggled a lot. The teaching video is quick and I had to rewatch it over and over. It doesn't feel like teaching. It just quickly shows you how to do it. You give guides on where to put things and how to do it, but it's confusing. Once again I had to learn how to figure what out what you wanted. Once I figured out how to understand the way you you try to explain things it was easier, but it was really frustrating to have to do that. You add some stuff for us already, which you would think would help but it interrupts the process of how we just learned how to do it step by step. If this is for people who know computers it's probably easy. I thought it was for someone who had no experience. I did learn  some and I feel much better about starting to learn to code. But I quit like 5 times and now that I've learned more about this field I look back and say wow that should have been much easier than it was. And the mistakes I made were just little, but it was because the quick video was just not actually teaching or really explaining. I've learned twice as much, and at a faster speed from a book I'm reading. If you are trying to get people to be apart of your code academy I would work on this five day challenge. Real teachers teach.  Bad teachers say read pages 5-10 and I'll quiz you tomorrow. That's not teaching, but it's how this felt and that's not a good first impression. I never right reviews but I just started to try to learn coding and I almost gave up because of this five day challenge. I'm sure computer savy people will see this as easy and feel smart, but someone like myself with no experience it just felt frustrating. I'm sure your actually institute isn't like this but it's not a good first impression. I hope this helps you because I almost gave up coding before I started out of frustration from this course.

This is a review of the the level 5 diploma in web application development.
The first two projects are centered around front end html, css and javascript. They are well laid out, easy to understand and implement. I passed them with a merit and pass grade. 
The third and fourth are back end with mostly django. For me it was almost impossible to follow the videos and i failed both projects. The difficulty of the second two projects was much higher than the first two and there was not enough time allocated to be able to understand what is being shown to you. Instead you are expected to copy the source code and when you have their code running edit it slightly before you submit it. I couldn't even get most of their code to work properly without alterations. Changing their development environment from gitpod to something else half way through the last project didn't help either. 
I asked if there was a lesser certificate that i could acheive based on the first two projects but there was not. I feel like i just wasted a year of my life and have nothing to show for the effort i put into this course. 
For the front end i would recommend code institute but the back end part is a mess in my opinion.

Jordan at Code Institute has been an outstanding conduit between my complete loss of where to start regarding learning coding, and getting me started on the most relevant course path within my financial means. He is very knowledgeable, personable and has the patient of a saint. 
After many many questions and a LOT of "umm'ing" and "errr'ing" from myself Jordan has enrolled me on the Front End Plus Pythonista course and I couldn't be happier. The coding languages taught on both of those courses make perfect sense for me to learn to both increase my value in my current work life and even offer potential for a career change, both of which I am buzzing about!
Thanks again Jordan, the help you have offered me on finding the most suitable course both time wise and financially has been above and beyond what I would ever have expected to receive.
If you are on the fence of whether to begin your coding journey through Code Institute go for it, the customer service is excellent and the course layout, content and resources is simply fantastic.

I joined Code Institute as a career changer trying to break into my first role within the tech industry. Coincidentally I managed to secure a role around the same time as starting the course. 
I had previously completed a skills bootcamp teaching me the basic skills however I quickly noticed that the course content is a lot more detailed than what I had already learnt, is easy to follow and well structured. As such I found that, even though early on, I was covering a lot of material I already knew, my understanding of it was really strengthened by the clear explanations and visual demonstrations. 
The structure of the course also easily allows you to manage at your own pace and I was easily able to schedule in my learning around my full time employment. 
All in all i would highly recommend the course for anyone looking to break into the industry or even just looking to really strengthen their technical skills.

Completing the Full Stack Software Developer Diploma at Code Institute was an enriching and transformative experience. The course content proved to be comprehensive, providing a solid foundation for grasping essential concepts and translating them into real-world applications. The robust support system, encompassing the vibrant Slack community, dedicated tutor assistance, and insightful mentorship, significantly contributed to my learning journey.
I must commend the efforts of the facilitators whose dedication to creating an engaging and supportive learning environment was truly commendable. Their guidance played a pivotal role in enhancing the overall educational experience.
Post-course completion, the assistance provided by the Career Support team was nothing short of remarkable. Their insights into industry trends, effective resume building, and practical career advice were invaluable as I transitioned into the professional sphere.
While my overall experience was highly positive, I believe there is always room for improvement. Specifically, I suggest a closer look at refining the learning materials for an even more seamless understanding. Additionally, providing clearer justification for assessment objectives could enhance the transparency of the evaluation process.
In conclusion, the Full Stack Software Developer Diploma at Code Institute is a program I wholeheartedly recommend for those seeking a comprehensive education coupled with strong support structures. Despite my suggestions for improvement, the overall impact of the course on my skills and career trajectory has been undeniably positive.

I would not recommend code institute to a beginner. If you plan on attending this course 1 year is to prefer or you risk burning yourself out. Sure you learn alot on the course and some things are really good like the standups each week to discuss and troubleshoot with the group about code issues for the current submission projects.
But some of the course video material is very outdated and not easy to follow for a beginner. I would say you should have some prior knowledge of coding or someone back home to ask about coding issues or this course will be to much. Half the time you spend trying to fix the issues of outdated versions that no longer exist or has changed. The javascript learning material which is the hardest to learn is a dissaster with all teoretical reading of concepts. I learned more by watching youtube code videos than following the course videos. The assessment of the submission projects is also extremely strict and unforgiving meaning that if you have missed on only one thing you will get a fail regardless of what it is, which I find very unmodern and estranged from the world. Your projects must also follow the design of each walkthrough project or you risk not getting any help. But with all that negative out of the way its still an introduction to start coding, get support and start leaning how to teach yourself new skills and languages. But its not as easy as they advertise it.

I recently completed the 5DCC challenge focused on HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Here’s my straightforward take:
1. Challenge’s Difficulty: For beginners, the challenge seemed too basic, lacking depth and complexity needed to truly engage or challenge.
2. Relevance of Tasks: The tasks felt outdated for 2023. Web design and development have evolved far beyond the concepts presented in the challenge, making it seem somewhat disconnected from current industry trends.
3. Lecture Format: Pre-recorded lectures significantly underperform compared to live webinars. While live sessions might be less convenient for some, they offer richer, real-time learning experiences. The inclusion of recorded sessions for those unable to attend live could be a balanced approach.
4. Outdated Content: The material, evidently not updated for over a year, misses the mark in delivering fresh, up-to-date insights crucial for tech learning.
5. Overall Impression for Prospective Students: The experience over these five days shapes one’s perception of the entire Code Institute’s curriculum. Live interaction and a more current syllabus would likely leave a more favorable impression.
6. Expectations from Code Institute: I’m hopeful and confident that Code Institute’s full program is far more relevant and in-depth than what this challenge portrayed. However, the experience of these five days should better reflect the quality and modernity of the institute’s offering.

The order of some of the directions to me where not in line with the way you'd naturally think about building a website in your head. Also you guys should use colour coding fonts in the written steps to also to match to where it goes in the coding elements, this cl could assist people learning coding easier by with colour association for certain code functions or actions. Maybe not such a bad thing peeps are not told language is American standard, trying to spot syntax errors is not a bad thing though I think spell checking the code is probably standard these days. You should have a group assignment as well to get people involved with each other to talk earlier on otherwise peeps be thinking I'm just talking to bots here :) I'd be having the coding assistant online and reaching out to the different region and telling the joiners the supporting coders hours off availability and lunch time on their profile where it can be seen very clearly. You'd probably be better off giving people a time schedule i.e we start at 9:30 am take X amount for break and finish at 5:00 pm or start at 8:30 am finishing at 4:30 pm. Whatever you guys feel would suit. You should also have Oauth and API integration for W3 school (GitHub etc.) and a few other helpful online tools so peeps know where to find them and what they do. So an Introduction to online tools to help in coding challenge will also benefit peeps! Have people from different locations across a shared timezone join the group along with one other from same country for group challenge if possible (maybe automation with bots can help with that). I would have like to build something to test my knowledge i.e go here and now build the following on your own webpage. Then I could share with loved ones and say "Look what I built!". The Code Institute is definitely the way to go as it can be adopted for primary schools and Universities alike! Best of luck! 🍀

Code Institute har varit mitt livs största misstag. Det utlovas alldeles för mycket, men i verkligheten stämmer ingenting. Kursen är alldeles för svår för nybörjare, dålig undervisning och nästan ingen hjälp alls. Sedan påstår de att 90% av eleverna får jobb direkt. Vilket är skitsnack. Flera studenter blir klara men får inte ens tekniskt supports tjänster. Eller ens blir kallade till intervju. För mig har den här resan handlat om att överleva hårda deadline och mycket förväntningar för en kurs som bara kostar pengar. Om man missar deadline då får man betala böter på 150€. Och om man inte klarar av godkänt så får man betala en avgift på 50€ !!! Kursen är så svårt och jag skulle inte rekommendera det för någon. När man betalar närmare 70 000 kronor är det svårt att bara hoppa av! Gå en ordentlig svensk utbildning är mitt råd till alla som funderar på att lära sig programmering. Det finns ingen som blir programmerare på 40 veckor med tanke på hur mycket det är att lära sig och ta in. Jag ser framemot att avsluta kursen och gå vidare med livet utan Code institute!!

The course content is very good if you have no knowledge of coding. It was insightful to see if this was something that would be capable of learning and how difficult I would find it. I’m not from a tech background so I was not expecting this to get me a job but the certificate is a nice incentive albeit rather useless. 
The only reason I gave it 4 stars and not 5 was for these reasons. 
1. The speaker rushes through the video in a monotonous way. I had to pause the video and read the transcript because it was as if he was speaking one long gigantic sentence instead of bullet points or paragraphs. 2. I understood most of the 5 day tasks eventually but it took a lot of rewatching or asking a friend who pointed out that the guidelines for passing the module were more strict than reality. ( spaces when there didn’t need to be one etc). 
3. The second day was massively more difficult than the others. I don’t know why but it felt as if the other people in the chat forum were also experiencing the same. 
4. The tasks were not really clear all the time. Especially day 2 and day 5 I didn’t really know what I was supposed to do and it took hours to figure it out. 
5. The speaker could have explained on the alternative routes to practice. ( using notepad and saving as .html, using Firefox under developer mode [f12] ) so that we could use debugging.

The 5 day coding challenge has been a great way to take my first steps in coding. It is well structured and it has a clear step by step approach. Moreover, I was approached by a contact person for the next steps in the application and he has been extremely helpful.

The tutorials were all in simple English. The approach of showing how to apply concepts being introduced is superb. Your programming IDE for learning is very fine. Generally I like the experience. I recently completed the 5-day coding challenge at Code Institute, and I would like to share my observations and feedback regarding the experience.
As a blind individual, I rely on a screen reader to navigate the challenges and the website. I found the website to be quite accessible overall. The challenges were well-structured, easy to follow, and made a lot of sense. The instructional videos were also well-explained, and I found it relatively easy to follow along. However, I did come across some accessibility issues that I believe need to be addressed, especially considering that this is a company focused on software development.
While the buttons for running and testing the code were visible to my screen reader, I encountered difficulty in locating the button to reset the entire code. This is a crucial functionality that needs to be made accessible immediately. To work around this issue, I resorted to copying all the code into a notepad file so that I had access to the original code.
Additionally, when watching the videos, I found the transcriptions to be quite good. However, it would have been helpful to have a transcript of the code as well. Currently, the code is only displayed on the screen, which makes it a bit challenging to follow along, especially for individuals who are not familiar with coding and are using a screen reader. Fortunately, I already possess coding knowledge, so I was able to understand the content of the videos. But for someone without coding experience and relying on a screen reader, this could prove to be very difficult.
In conclusion, I wholeheartedly recommend the 5-day coding challenge offered by Code Institute. However, I must mention that I am giving it a rating of 3 out of 5 due to the aforementioned accessibility issues. While these issues may seem minor or insignificant, it is essential for me to highlight the importance of prioritizing accessibility in all companies, including those involved in software development.

The best way for humans to learn is to set targets. In x days you will know how to do this & state why that is important, link to real world business needs if needs be. That sort of thing. But using the coding tools, Slack, GitHub etc is very reflective of core tools used by most companies these days. Keep it as practical as possible. IT to me is no different a skill to learn in terms of experience as any Stem role, we learning from doing i.e. mechanics, electricians,  builders, etc. The course material & backend infrastructure and the lack of meeting people face to face would need to be addressed. You would also need to have Government buy in etc. Security, privacy etc. Lots to consider. Very interesting process though!

I signed up for the Code Institute's free 5-Day Coding Challenge course as a way to find out what coding is, if I'm any good at it, and if it might be a good fit as a career change for me.
I was really impressed by the level of attention and support the Code Institute provided from the beginning. They sent several emails, but nothing "spammy", just bona fide info on how to access the course, additional learning resources via their YouTube tutorials, and invitations to contact them with any questions.
The course is delivered through pre-recorded video messages, and they also hosted a community discussion group on Slack. It was led and monitored by a Code Institute rep. 
The videos were great, they include a written version of everything said on the video - very important for me as a visual learner, and also helpful to quickly find and review one detail of the lesson material without having to click through the whole vid. Also makes things very accessible for those whose first language is not English, or people with auditory issues. The presenter speaks with an Irish accent, so if you're not used to that the transcript can be helpful.
A little spoiler alert - the second day is a pretty steep learning curve so don't get discouraged if you feel out of your depth. I got through it by taking extra time to work on it, reviewing the video carefully and making notes, and by using the Slack chat. That was crucial to success - there are tons of other people doing the challenge, and people are often sharing helpful tips or screen shares showing how they approached it.

I am recent graduate of Code Institute, having checked Trustpilot a year ago for reviews, and thought now that, as I took the leap of faith and graduated, that I'd write what I'd consider a fair review. Obviously, this comes from my personal experience.
I will start this off by saying that if you are looking to start this course believing that you will be magically granted a job right at the end, then I would say this is the completely wrong reason to study software development. Code Institute do have some fantastic resources and contacts to get you closer into the job market, and you can definitely lean on them for guidance, however no institution can guarantee you a job.
Having said that, a vast many alumni, graduating from Code Institute, get a job within 6-8 months. I have even seen as much as 2 months. A minority gain jobs while on the course however this is a bit more rare and probably more luck-induced or they have contacts. 
Focusing on the course itself and material: I loved it. As someone who was mingling in and out of coding with Python beforehand and had no idea of what "roadmap" to take, Code Institute supplied that. I learnt the following: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, PostgreSQL, Bootstrap, Flask, Django Framework, React.js and Django REST Framework. GitHub Pages and Heroku were used (during my experience) to host live projects. Your 5th project is a specialisation project and you can pick between E-Commerce, Advanced Front-End and Data Science.
Now, it's very easy to say "you can just learn any of these on your own or for much less". Well of course you can. You can learn anything on your own rather than join an academic institution. Before doing this I was an avid polyglot and I could learn French on my own without the need for higher education. However some people go to university or do courses. It's no biggie. What Code Institute does offer, contrary to doing it by one's self, is guidance, structure, mentor and tutor support, a community (I have networked with hundreds of more people than I could've expected au debut) and career support. There are even hackathons, which are carried out by a voluntary group and has been growing in popularity. The experience from this has been one of the best aspects of the course. I grew close to my mentor, whom I consider an absolute gem, and even had another mentor for my final specialisation project, and who was also brilliant. This sort of support has been instrumental in my confidence-building and insight into the tech industry. To top this off, the diploma at the end of the scheme is university-rated, which makes it a meaningful document if you wish to take this to higher level studies. 
Code Institute do offer a payment plan too, you can pick between several. Some people have managed it via a grant or other ways. Personally, the payment plan was perfect, tight at times but it was very doable. Whether they will continue to offer this in future time after this review, obviously I am unsure but I don't see why not.
You do this course as fast or slow as you like. If you already know HTML and CSS, great, speed through the sections to work up on what you know, get to know your mentor and get working on your first project. You'll have saved yourself some good time for the much harder projects which are to come. The greatest thing about this course is that I could continue to work my rather awkward job with awkward and often unpredictable hours and complete the course material. For me that was primordially important and a rare opportunity in my life. 
So overall, thank you Code Institute for everything :- ) I am especially pleased with my experience.

I recently took a coding course with Code Institute, and unfortunately, I feel like they fell short on their promises. After submitting a complaint and planning a call with the team, I wanted to send a letter explaining my concerns regarding the areas of support that were sold to me but not delivered, ultimately hindering my learning.
My complaint initially had three main points: tutor support time allocation and the consequences of exceeding 45 minutes, video call availability, and guaranteed check-ins every four weeks, as per the CI material.
Although I wish the calculation of time used was based on the entire course rather than weekly usage, I am content with the explanation provided regarding how tutor support time is allocated, as it is fair and transparent - especially after receiving recent emails to students. Therefore, I am willing to move on from the first point without any further issues.
Initially, I had trouble receiving support from tutors with coding issues related to the course, which led me to wonder why I wasn't offered any video support. I spoke with other students, including some alumni, and none of them had ever been offered video support.
On February 28th, 2022, I received a response from CI stating that "Due to capacity reasons, the tutors are not currently offering screen shares, so video support is unavailable for now." However, from my understanding (and what was sold to me), video support was a key feature in the support package sold by CI. When I asked for confirmation on when video support was stopped, I was advised on March 2nd, 2022, that "My colleagues have advised that this was discontinued about 6 weeks ago." Later, on March 11th, 2022, I received an update that "Just following up on this, my colleagues have confirmed that the recent break from video calls is a temporary measure, and they're due to be reintroduced in the next month. They've also noted that these calls are not by request, but are provided where a tutor feels the situation requires due to particularly difficult coding errors that the tutor needs a better look at to help the student overcome the problem." I would like to understand the criteria used to define a particularly difficult coding error, as I consider spending over 4 ½ hours on a coding issue at minimum to be a difficult coding error, and I cannot understand why video support would not be offered. From my research and experience, I find it hard to believe that any video support has been offered since I became a customer of CI. No one from the community can confirm receiving video support, and I've had multiple 4-hour+ tickets with multiple tutors without any offer of video support. This was a key selling point when I decided to purchase CI, and I feel misled.
Regarding the third component - guaranteed check-ins every four weeks, as per the CI material - it was confirmed that I didn't receive a call for 14 weeks. In an email sent by CI on March 30th, 2022, it was stated that "I can see you didn't receive a call-based check-in due to changes to the team during the 14 weeks between August 30th, 2021, and December 6th, 2021." However, in response, it was said that "During that time, 6 emails, covering a variety of topics to keep you engaged and reiterating how to access your supports, were sent along to help keep you on track." I checked to see if I missed.
Following the completion of PP2 the support was not delivered. The 14 weeks were still paid for in full and so far there has not been an answer to why the support sold has not been delivered. In total the course is £6,500 over 12 months. 14 weeks of that is equal to £1,750. Failure to deliver what was sold to me has cost me over £2,000 in either direct losses or consequences from failure of the delivery. 
The reason I chose Code Institute over any other provider was the support package sold to me. When deciding on who to go with, CI led heavily on the strong support from having tutoring (1:1 support) including video calls, instant messages and emails, the assigned mentors and slack channel. Unfortunately this hasn’t been delivered, I’m dissatisfied that what was sold to me has not been delivered.

This a review of the 5 day code challenge:
Don't get me wrong. It's a great experience and a unique introduction to HTML & CSS for absolute beginners. Less about JS.
Day 1 to day 4, HTML and CSS, were good.
However, I think day 5 was my least favourite. 
I had hoped to see something about the layout in CSS.
 I would have arranged the content differently over the days, so that they could also see this. 
It would have been nice if we could display different lay-outs with media queries across different screen sizes. 
In addition, please spend a little more time on JS, because I think you went over that just a little too quickly and explained less well than the previous days.
The JS section was just a copy and paste excercicese. So, not a real challenge.
In my opinion, with layout in CSS and JS you discover more if writing code is something for you.
It didn't even bother me that copyright 2023 gave error message. (in the video (c) 2018, in the exercise (c) 2022). But when you update these videos, remember my tips!
Together with tips and tricks from experienced coders and a behind the scene from code institute students how followed the courses in the past, would be nice. Because your courses aren't not high recommended on the internet. Not because the are very expensive, with hidden costs and and with the same problems as the 5 day code challenge.
Maybe you should make the code challenge a week long, the video's are prerecorded,  where we have the weekend for extra lessons and to deal with the info overload.
We also missed some interaction on the slack forum. it was kind of dead. Questions remained unanswered. Perhaps make arrangements when someone from code institute can help answer questions. 
I think you can get a lot further on solo learn or freecodecamp, with the same amount of time to spend. We're going to try that now.

It wasn't really a coding challenge, it was more like a very basic introduction to a couple of html concepts. For CSS, all it asked was to copy a line of code or a value onto a specific space. For JavaScript (the 3rd out of 3 exercises of the last day only), it was also just "copy this line", and the line was wrong (it generated the wrong response in browser, and if you tried to write the right command, the exercise was marked as incorrect). Before I finished day 5, a sales representative called me congratulating me on the "great results" (?!), asking if I had coded before (?!), and started talking about the paid programme. I said I was already enrolled for a bootcamp in another school, and he -very inelegantly- said, "Sure, you can do these little [name of the school], but if you really want to become a professional, give us a call". Don't know why so smug. No good school needs to do this, so that's the impression that I get. Also: if the lessons are going to be in the rhythm and style of this 5-day sample, maybe it's a good idea to have a video control panel that allows 4x speed. The man in the video speaks so slowly and makes so many weird long pauses in weird places, that when he's finished the sentence, you don't remember what it was about. There are teleprompters, guys. And some teleprompters even have remote controls so you can adjust the scroll speed to your speaking rhythm.

Don't enroll! The 5day challenge is fun but the full course is nothing like it. There is no flexibility once you are behind the course you are all on your own. You can pay a fee for each deadline you miss. They'll grant you leave of absence which has no point as the course is not available during this time. There is no solution once you fall behind. No help, just payments. That the course requires just 12 hrs a week is a LIE. Once you are done with the first 2 projects, the training material changes and it's no videos etc. Just hoping that someone in the community will have time to explain things. You'll have to spend atleast 20 hours a week the minimum. No refund, no option to quit regardless of your difficult personal circumstances.

I've tried the 5 Day Coding Challenge to get back into coding after ten years and I'm positively surprised!
Code Institute implemented a lot of useful videos (each with "subtitles" at the side) for each day and it only uses up to one hour per day. Even less, if you've already got some experience. It covers HTML, CSS and JavaScript basics.
While taking part in each challenge there's a little tool that tells you whether or not you've gotten all the assignments correct. If you don't have something correct it gives you a tip on what to do. Although the tip is not that great because it only says: „Did you make an XXX command? Does it have YYY?“, which isn't very helpful in my opinion.
But if you're stuck you can join a group for the five days where you can get help from a professional and/or talk to fellow challengers!
Also, if you don't get around to finish all of your challenges within the five day period don't worry! In my case they automatically stretched my access to the course until the end of the weekend!
Tldr; it's a really great resource and I recommend it to anyone interested in coding!

It started with the onboarding call. I already have some experience with programming and I was trying to get information if I would benefit from joining code institute. The person I spoke to didn't have any technical knowledge, which is understandable - the program is set up for people with zero experience. But instead of helping me, he merely shifted me to the five day coding challenge... Which I already knew was going to be a waste of time. But I decided to play along since maybe I would be able to speak to someone else. In the coding challenge we were all set up in a slack group. There, again, I asked to speak about my concerns, but my question was left unanswered. And so were my other questions regarding the autograder. All I got were canned responses to talk to onboarding people. The whole system (from what I was able to experience up to that point) is set up in such a way it takes people in and spits them out. There's no room for independent thought / solving edge cases. I say this having the experience of talking to two other institutions where I was able to get my questions escalated to people who could talk to me. And in one of those cases I was able to talk to an instructor where we came to the conclusion that particular bootcamp wouldn't be right for me. I was not able to get that from code institute.

I find it fundamentally untrustworthy that most of these reviews are for the five day challenge when what people care about is spending the money on the main course. bad practice. 
This is a review of my personal experience doing the Code Institute course, starting in July 2019. I had almost no experience with programming at the start of the course. 
On the plus side:
Their student care team is very active and responds quickly
Being on the course held me to a deadline
Because the coursework is assessed it pushes you to finish off and polish the projects 
There is a slack community
It provides a structure to follow (which technologies)
The negative:
-- They teach things that are factually incorrect. 
-- They do not teach good best practices. That creates problems later on. 
-- They do not explain why they do things, or how things fit together. Core concepts etc. 
-- Added things between videos and not said anything. This means your code doesn’t work properly but you don’t know why.  
-- Many places where they say 'ok, this bit is hard to understand,  you may need to re-watch the video' but they don't explain really what's happening
-- They don't teach set up. Course is in gitpod, a  sandbox environment.  don't teach you about development environments, setting up projects etc... 
-- The marking criteria is unspecific
-- They do not tell you the overall grading system
-- I was marked down harshly for things that were not in the marking criteria
--The student care team functions like a badly run HR department. They can’t really do much except ‘take feedback’
--Slack community support is other students (not teachers)
--Tutors not available as promised, limited sessions, no help understanding or teaching, not very useful
--Jobs in their portal not actual coding jobs
I have been getting through this course with the help of some really great Udemy courses that actually teach you how things work and why. I have also had a lot of help and personal tutoring from my partner who has had to fill in a lot of the gaps. The time I have spent trying to follow along with the bad learning material has actually left me with emotional PTSD, where I end up in tears because i’m so frustrated and angry… days and weeks after I have had to try and learn through them. 
The closest I can describe my learning experience with them is that feeling you have as a child in a classroom, when the teacher is moving fast and not really explaining things, and you are lost, but they won’t stop or answer questions. The blood pounds in your ears and your chest is tight. You are trapped, you can’t get out because you are in their class all year, you know an exam is coming. You know that you will not do well. The teacher, knowing that you have not been following, still picks on you to answer questions, even though your face is wet with tears. Every day.

Although I haven't completed the course yet (approx. 75% done) I cannot recommend Code Institute highly enough. The course content is structured in a way that encourages self development alongside the provision of the fundamentals needed to break into a coding career.
I admit I was sceptical at the early stages, there were a few discrepancies compared with the very latest information from some documentation - this is, however, a really key thing to learn in the industry, things change quickly! The course content is updated fairly regularly to reflect the changes in the industry and the biggest thing I have taken from it is that they have taught me the skills to investigate and further my own knowledge. 
The career support and advice is fantastic, many of my peers are already landing roles in the industry and the community (run on an application called Slack) is amazing! So many aspiring/exisiting developers all offering advice and input.
On top of the course, they run hackathon events most months, giving you an opportunity to collaborate in a more "real-world" scenario. These events have opened my eyes to even more coding practices and the way things operate within a team. Participation in these also appear to be very well received on CVs.
Overall, it has been (and continues to be) a thoroughly enjoyable and educational experience...you have to put the effort in, but doing so will lead to a far better experience!

I base this review on the free Five Day Coding Challenge that I recently completed.
I took the coding challenge not to see if coding was for me, but as a practical review exercise for some lecture based online courses I had taken beforehand about HTML, CSS and JavaScript. For those purposes, it worked well enough.
While the coding challenge was not difficult overall, most of the concepts were overly basic in the three languages, I felt it was perhaps too easy in ways it should have been more challenging.
One thing that bothered me, when I tried to follow the transcripts that ran with the video segments, is that there are several errors in the transcripts. It's like they only used a computer to create the transcript and didn't have a human double check it. As a native English speaker with no hearing impairments, I could get what I needed from the presenter. However, I could imagine non-native English speakers or those with hearing impairments having serious issues with using the transcripts.
As for the content of the code challenge itself, I feel they overhype it a bit in their advertising. Based on what I've learned the very basics are of HTML, CSS and JS from the other online courses I've taken, I feel the coding challenge may not go deep enough to give someone who's a complete newcomer to coding a complete enough taste of the basics to make a truly informed decision if coding is right for them.
My main advice to Code Institute: Fix your video transcripts and consider making the Code Challenge two weeks long so you can go deeper with the basics and make the substance of the challenge match the hype you give it.
As the Five Day Code Challenge was free, and it served the purposes I had for taking it, I won't critique further.
Just keep in mind, you get what you pay for.

Firstly – I apologise for the novel. This is only the highlights from the issues I faced while attending a course with this college.
I would like to convey very clearly that I am exceptionally unimpressed with this course. I have found it far below the standards that I would expect from a course partnered with UCD (well technically UCD Professional Academy). Furthermore, I feel the cost of €7995 cannot possibly be justified given the poor quality of the teaching and the course material itself.
Unfortunately Trustpilot does not provide a big enough comment box to list out my legitimate concerns for courses from this college. for full details go: www. reddit .com/r/DevelEire/comments/k8lrqn/code_institute_anyone/
The biggest issue:
Changing assessment criteria while students are actively working on the projects in question (initially without telling the applicable students). When this was raised a response of "simplifying assessment criteria to inflate pass rates is acceptable because employers will not know and it is done all the time in third level education"... This, in my opinion, is just wrong and confirms that this certificate will not have any real industry value.
The promised content was not delivered. Even the Customer Services the Manager for their partnered school admitted that mistakes have been made with this course and that the level of service provided has not met the expectations of any party involved
[UPDATE BASED ON REPLY] The purpose of this review is not too discuss the issues (all attempts of resolution were provided by your partner college UCD, not CI), but to warn prospective students of the experience I had so they can be aware of the experience they can expect. And so they can be aware that much of the "programme's different aspects" promised were not actually provided, and the few that were, were substandard

The course started with the 5 day coding challenge it was made in the way, to make me think that once I pass it, will mean, that I am pretty skilled in this area “of thinking”. It consisted of tasks in HTML and CSS. For somebody who has never touched coding, and does not know that HTM and CSS are very simple tools to learn in coding it is easy to fall in this TRAP to think that you will be good at it. Why not create 5 day coding challenge in JavaScrip or Python, much more complex languages???? 
It started of well as with HTML and CSS, but the JavaScript and Python modules were intensely complicated, with badly laid out theory, with end module challenges often with elements not corresponding to the course material making the challenges even more confusing. Majority of the time I was left to research the subjects in other resources on my own to understand what I was being taught. 
The tutor support are not allowed to give you straight answers (I have been taught that many times) plus you have to wait for their support 30/40min to 1.5 hrs. There is a limit of how often in a week you can ask for the support. So, if you have used them twice in a week you are unlikely to be helped third time in the same week or may wait more than 3hours.  The flow of conversation is very slow as tutors (many recent graduates) are talking chatting to other students at the same time. I had to wait for my answers in conversations between 20min to 1.5hrs. 9 out of 10 times tutor’s shift ended during the conversation and I was told to wait for another tutor for help. 
Mentor support your have is between 30-60 min three time during your project. 1 when you talk about your idea. 2 when you are in the middle but expectation is that you should have at this stage completed 70% of your work. 3 before the submission and when project is completed. This is not a help really as ideally you need at least 1-3hr every week to discuss many aspects and problems as this is a completely new field for you. The mentor would often send me to research my queries anyway. This is simply some tick box exercise for the provider of the course to make it look compliant and encouraging. 
They say that you can use 24hr support in Slack, used by students asking questions that are drown in a despair slowly learning that they have had wasted their money. There are many bugs in the tutorial content and for that reason, the end challenges do not work but you are not able to know whether that is your error in the challenge or something else. No to mention spelling mistakes. Tutorials refer to Cloud9 but you have to use completely different GitPod … this list can go on, it is very depressing.  
If you struggle with the content there is nobody to help you. Student support just make calls to you to tick box as they do not actually listen to your struggles. They count their time on the phone making sure it is not extended and you end up with no substantial support to what you are asking for. 
For every late submission you pay extra fee, for every resubmission you pay extra fee. With the above support it could be an endless and costly experience. 
This course is for people with prior knowledge of coding in all offered coding languages. For a beginner is an absolute nightmare as you don’t know what you are doing therefore a lot of support is needed. You will be left completely abandoned with your issues the only real savior can be a developer friend if he/she has a lot of time to give you some attention.
CI put a lot of careful attention into getting you into the course 5day VERY EASY coding challenge, with many email reminders, marketing and getting your money. I can give them 5* for the three areas. You will be better off studying on your own. Do not pay for this course unless you have a lot of previous coding experience or you are a beginner but a complete genius! Otherwise, you will pay thousands to learn how to google or use Stack Overflow. 
I have chucked this course in the middle of it’s run, learning from free and better explained resources  and have never been happier since.

I signed up to the code institute full stack developer course during the pandemic whilst on Furlough. There wasn't any assessment they were just happy to take £6000 off me, during that period we had to home school our two children and I was eventually made redundant. My mentor who was based outside of the UK had an appalling connection whenever we spoke and eventually resigned, I was allocated a new mentor who never made contact. My wife also had to leave her job for medical reasons, I requested extensions which were not granted so I asked to leave the course to focus on my family. To retrain in an entirely new field requires a lot of time, effort and concentration and my circumstances had changed significantly. I asked for a partial refund as I had only accessed the online portal and had not submitted any projects, this was denied for no justifiable reason. I have since read in other reviews that partial refunds have been issued so I am hoping that somebody will now contact me to discuss. I am so disappointed with the lack of empathy and understanding of peoples circumstances during the most difficult of my and many peoples lives. Be careful if you are looking to sign up, many people may have had a more positive experience than myself but I would approach with caution.

The 5 Day Coding Challenge is a well-paced and engaging introduction to learning the fundamentals of HTML, CSS and JavaScript. 
The course is delivered in an accessible, jargon-free way and perfect for anyone who is curious to know if coding is a subject area that they would like to pursue further knowledge of.

What went well?
I overall like the structured approach of the program, and how it thought me a lot about the basics of the 3 languages in 5 days. Although I didn't make use of the help channels provided, I liked that they were there if any of us needed any help. 
What could be improved?
What I didn't like about the exercises was that they weren't really flexible in terms of the answers I gave them. For example for making my recipe website, I couldn't really customize it, and sometimes even though the code was correct and worked fine, it was marked wrong because it wasn't the exact code you expected me to write. So the exercises weren't open to creativity and flexibility. Also it would have been nice if the answer of one exercise, like the css for my recipe website would also be used for the css in later exercises.

I completed my diploma in Full Stack Web Development with Code Institute in March 2020.  Since then I have been working freelance as a software developer, learning new technologies as often as I can.  The course gave me some fantastic skills and I enjoyed being part of the wonderful Code Institute slack Community - there were always wonderful people available to help when coding went wrong, and if I needed more help the tutor service was great.  I also had a mentor who was very supportive but also encouraged me to find solutions for myself and gave me tips on best ways to do this.  I feel that the course was reasonably priced and that I got very good value for my investment.   Finally at the end of the course the careers module was full of useful information and since I completed the course I have been able to participate in hackathons as an alumni and worked with some students on the course to create some wonderful apps.

It was my first hackathon and I was quite nervous about working in a team. Thankfully it turned out a very rewarding yet challenging experience. Code Institute had all the necessary supports in place if we needed them.
My take away experience from the hackathon is that it has made me see the gaps in my knowledge and where I need to apply myself more. It also made me realise how important it is to work well within a development team.

Meeting industry experts and having their feedback for our projects provided a greater understanding of the industry as a whole and how to prepare for the work place both from a working perspective and an interview skills perspective. Although I did benefit from taking this course to some extent, I have more than a few reservations about it and would honestly not recommend it, particularly if you are investing your own savings in the hope of a career change, you could be bitterly disappointed.  
First of all, if you are hesitating do not fall for their free five-day coding challenge, it is far superior to the “full stack” course (like the all option model car dealers put on display!) and is designed to lure customers in what is, at best, a mediocre course sold at an extortionate price.  
For me, the biggest disappointment is the complete lack of any pedagogy throughout the course. You won’t speak to any teacher but will be showed hundreds of mind-numbing videos, presenting different pieces of code, that you are expected to reproduce pretty much exactly, without any understanding of what you are doing. To make matters worse, some of them will be out of date by the time you have watched them. The quality of the material is inconsistent ranging from good (HTML)to poor (Javascript and Jquery) and contains various typos and errors. The lack of pedagogy is particularly evident in the harder sections of the course (Javacript, Python, Databases), to be competent in those requires a lot more (for me at least) than what this course covers which is disappointing for the price. 
The interactive content on repl.it is more interesting even though the tasks that you must complete are generally too easy, however, if you decide to try the “challenge tasks” you will be lucky if you can understand the intricate instructions! 
One strength of the course is its support system of tutoring and mentoring, which is decent (depending on who you talk to), but again it does not quite live up to the promises of the brochure (24/7 support...). You interact with tutors through a live chat but waiting times can be quite long (up to 90 minutes), not ideal when you are working on a tight schedule. Some tutors are brilliant and really go out of their way to help you, some could not care less (“do what it says on the video”).   
When you’re working on one of the compulsory projects and are trying to implement some functionalities that are slightly different from those shown in the videos they will often say “we don’t offer help on things that are not in the course” yet for some project you are expected to go beyond what is in the course and do your own research because “it’s a useful developer’s skill”. 
Your mentor is a professional of the industry who is supposed to help you with your projects, mine was nice enough but could not really get down to my level and most of the time I had no idea what he was talking about! 
In the Slack forum, you will find answers to a lot of questions but because most of my questions had already been answered, I could not really interact with anyone. Also, judging on the conversations, it was clear that a lot of people on the course were not beginners or had a far better understanding about the course content, which made it rather intimidating. 
The “full stack“ course is designed to be marketable, and make you believe that it can get you the basic skills to be able to work with anything from HTML to Javascript, Python, databases etc. In reality, it just brushes on those topics, shows you one or two example which you then copy and that’s it.  I was able to complete 3 out 4 modules without really understanding anything that I was doing and just fell short on the last one for lack of time. 
In terms of dealing with issues and offering extensions they were fairly flexible in the end, but it did take a few unpleasant phone conversations to get there, which did not make for a good customer experience (even though you hear a lot about good UX in the course!). 
To conclude, I would say that if money is not an issue, if you need a diploma to acknowledge your skills as a developer or if you have previous coding experience and want to extend your skills, then this course might be for you. Otherwise, if you are looking tentatively at new career options, I would recommend looking at cheaper courses and free material, there are plenty available on the web (just check some You Tube channels) whose quality is just as good. There is not much, in my opinion, that justifies the asking price for this course and even though I did learn a few things, I regret the money I have spent and feel like a fool for falling for their marketing.

I enrolled for the five-day coding challenge out of curiosity...ended up enjoying the content and the learning style so much that I enrolled for the Full-Stack developer course!

There are 4 practical projects that you can show up in your github and a lot of practising exercises on each of the 4 big modules. The course curriculum is really good and well structured it is including the latest real contents currently used in companies, I've seen many of the contents used in the start up tech company, where I used to work. 
The student portal used to have frequent errors, at least in the time I did the course, although is easy to use, (moving among lessons inside one module is easy) but very annoying when trying to move among modules to one specific lesson, I missed a more accessible/less-clicks/page reloads way to get to any point of any module.
Deadlines are VERY rigid for finishing the projects, if you are currently a full-time employee (normal 8h/day) is practically impossible to really learn everything from the course, you can finish the course and follow it yes, but you will finish with the feeling of not really learning, because you are constantly rushing to get to deadlines, moving to the next lesson without being able to go deeper as long you need in any specific topic.
You will end up with a vague general understanding of each field, definitely not enough for the price of the course.
I would recommend this course only if you are  not full-time employed and if you have money.
Pro
The course curriculum, and the students community in Slack
Con 
Way too expensive for the kind of "support" you actually receive.
Most of the time you end up asking among the other students community rather than getting actual support from mentors, as they are only there for general guidance in your projects, not to help you solve code problems.
Your access to the portal and study contents is removed once you finish the course, which to me makes no sense at all, and forces you to take extra separate notes, using more time for notes that could be used to actually practice.
The interviews/job finding preparation is a joke, you can get the same advice and support anywhere free in internet as they don't communicate with you directly.
The last module of the course corresponding to the last project, is way too long in content/complexity compared with the rest of the other 3 modules, which is normal but you still have the same time to complete it than the previous, which adds additional pressure.

The Code Institute Diploma in Full Stack Development (Software Development) provides a solid grounding in Full Stack Development technologies and software development processes enabling students to easily apply for junior development positions and extending their knowledge and skills gained during the course with the latest languages, tools, frameworks, and processes.
The course is well structured and contains a series of micro-lectures that are easy to follow and understand. There are plenty of challenges along to way to sharpen one's new knowledge and skills, and a series of graded projects to prove ones understanding of the concepts.
One of the best things is the excellent support structure with Mentors, Tutors, and Student Support. On top of that, there is a vibrant and supportive global Slack Community with peers willing and able to help.
The Slack Community Leads and peers share knowledge through sessions, such as Object-Oriented Python and JavaScript programming, Flask and Django frameworks (above and beyond what is covered on the course), and the use of new technologies.
You will receive a solid understanding and application of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, Flask and Django frameworks, Bootstrap and Materialize, SQL (PostgreSQL, MySQL) and no-SQL (MongoDB) databases, and some of the latest front-end frameworks.
The graded projects solidify your knowledge and skills and provide you with a portfolio to share with potential employers.
One other point that is brilliant are the frequent Hackathons where you work with team members from across the globe on a full-stack solution. This is another project to show your future employer.
The Code Institute are responsive to improvements and are continuously improving the course material.
I think a fair grade is 4.5 stars. ⭐️  There is always room for improvement.

I do wish that the Code Institute representatives were more active within the channel, there wasn't much connection established during the week.  I can understand that the purpose of the channel was for peers to help solve each others' problems, however when it came to individuals struggling to find their certificate etc, I saw very little help from the representatives and these are not the kinds of problems that peers are meant to tackle for the purpose of this course.  
The webinar at the end of the week provided some insight as to how the coding industry works and what employers in relevant fields are looking for, although a lot of it was the promotion of their Bootcamp course, understandably so.  It's not entirely a negative point, it is very useful if individuals are interested in taking up the course in the first place.  It's something to consider for some people.  
All in all, I have learned the very basics and it has given me a boost in being able to learn more by myself and work on my own thing.  Very useful course for an absolute beginner.

I thought the Coding Institute Challenge I just undertook over the past week was really, really great- I thought it was a very good introductory set-up for someone like me who had never coded in the given coding languages. The explanations were thorough- especially, in making sure that most details which may be very obvious to someone who has coded and used programming interfaces in prior, but not to someone who hasn't, were explained.
On this latter note however, I feel it would have been very useful to potentially explain further about the sub-elements entered into the head element, as this part was sort of brushed over (to find out more about these parts I turned to a very useful youtube tutorial for this). I would have also appreciated if further information was provided surrounding how you actually get the website up and running on the internet- and further discussion surrounding on how the script you write is first stored locally, and what one can do to then get a domain name and have your webpage stored on a server.
Additionally, I feel that the tutor component which was supposed to be available during the process was limited. When going through the challenges I had very specific questions which were related to, for example adding style to specific words instead of paragraphs or sections, or that were outside of the scope of the specific code of a challenge exercise. For these types of questions I felt it was hard to seek help via the tutor function.
Overall though, I felt the 5-day challenge was great, and its structure of mixing between shot-concise videos and exercises made it enjoyable, and easy to follow.
