I had an amazing journey with the Code Institute. I began the course with a real appetite and a desire to come out the other end with a Diploma and the skills and knowledge to know what it takes to build something using code.
The course content is housed on a very easy to navigate learning management system. It guided me through 12 modules covering Html, CSS, Javascript, Git, Bootstrap, Jquery, Jasmine Testing, Python, Mongo DB, Mysql Flask and finally Django.
Each module feeds into a core learning element which is cemented by means of submitting your very own Project - This is where the real learning happens. Following modules and lessons is fine - and you can nod your head through all of them. But when you get to the project - the gloves are off and it's time to get your hands dirty for real.
The first project, which is using just Html and CSS scared the socks off me - I really had no idea how to go about it - and its a battle with yourself to find a way through this using what has been taught, but also learning how to find answers on your own - a skill so invaluable once learned.
And that's the hidden Module that runs throughout this Diploma - You must learn that the course is a roadmap, but you must learn how to problem solve and utilise Google and any other means to overcome issues and bugs. This is after all the most precious skill of all and cannot be taught. So don't expect to be hand-fed every answer - the lessons are cleverly written to give you the core information, but many of the challenges and especially the projects will require you to be resourceful and find answers outside of the course content.
Other than Google you will find the Slack student community is an amazing resource of fellow students and Alumni - all willing to help one another and nudge you in the correct direction - again here - do not expect to get the answers on a plate, but you will definitely get the help you need. 
As Slack is made up of your fellow students it should be used with the proper respect for a fellow student, and is a place where you may ask for help - but not demand it. If Slack is unable to help there is an excellent support structure.
Tutor support can be contacted if you run into an issue you just cannot solve, again it is better for your learning journey to exhaust any other means first, but not to the extent where you get desperate or despondent - these guys are really smart and will help you out and point you in the right direction.
Overall I had a really good experience, but you will need to go into this with the correct attitude. It is your learning journey - don't expect to be hand-fed everything and be prepared to work hard for it - It's your future after all!! If you think that describes you - just go for it with both hands - I can promise you - You won't be disappointed!

I really loved this course. It is very well structured and there are plenty of exercises, challenges and projects to put your knowledge to proof. Also there is a big community of students, mentors and support team to help you on the way. Glad I found this course. Thank you.

The course is not cheap, and there are cheaper or free alternatives, e.g. Freecodecamp, which I tried before. But I find the course a good path for someone who wants to start from zero and have a structured process with clear objectives and deadlines. Although it was quite stressful at times, it definitely helped me to be more organized and staying on deadlines. 
The course videos are easy to follow, working on coding challenges was difficult at times, and i needed to do extra research or sometimes ask for help on student slack. It'd be good to have recommended resources to learn better certain topics. For example, algorithms or BigO notation were not really introduced in the course.
Each student works on a portfolio of 4 projects with progressively increasing complexity. The project task description seemed to be a bit too short, and lacking some guiding info. I used other students’ projects as an example, in planning, structuring my projects, writing documentation. Your grades depend on ticking all the necessary boxes in project assessment, which was not always clear to me. Some students make very simple projects, but because a project ticked all the boxes, they get a distinction. I tried to achieve more complexity in my projects, and sometimes a minor thing failed my assessment. This felt a bit unfair to overlook efforts put into complexity just because of a small thing, but I guess this is a structured approach. In any case two of my last projects went way over the material taught in the course. 
Initially I planned to complete the course in 6 months, but due to the covid, my family situation and over-complexing my projects, I did that in about 11 months. If you lack on time, I’d recommend not to over-complicate your projects, and you still can learn a lot and get your diploma.
I had three mentors over the course of 12 months. During planning and implementation of my first three projects I lacked assistance in planning, and during development. My last mentor was quite helpful and gave me good ideas, and answered my complicated questions. Overall, I believe some students are lucky to get good mentors, some are not. 
Tutor support was quite good, and I had a lot of challenges in my projects solved with the help of some of the tutors. But not all of them were knowledgeable. 
Student slack channel is a good resource, where there are a lot of experienced students plus tutors help you to solve your tasks or challenges. 
Generally, I was supported, but being connected to all of the people and resources only online, I felt some lack of support and guidance, but I guess it just adds to self-learning. 
Before I started the course, I thought I’d be ready to be hired once I am done. It is not like that though. I still need to learn additional frameworks/libraries, like React, or study algorithms for interviews. The Code Institute could improve this part in creating career paths with additional tech to learn. Or recommend learning some while implementing projects. I know that some students include React (which is not taught by the course) in their last project. 
Overall, the course is not cheap and has areas of improvement, but it gives a good start with a structure to learn and build your portfolio. Of course, you should do research and see if there are free alternatives, but don’t forget that you will have to create a structure for your work, targets for portfolio building, and follow your deadlines. If you look at other Bootcamps, besides comparing price and curriculum, have a look at what portfolio you will have on the way out, and check Github projects of students from different bootcamps. Code Institute definitely gave me a structure of how to plan, implement(code, comments, file system & names, etc), and document (readme) my projects.

An amazing insight into the world of coding, that was informative and easy to follow, with just enough challenge to keep it interesting and fantastic support through the use of Slack. Highly recommend to anyone that is curious about where to start with their journey into coding.

When an ad popped up on my Instagram about the 5 Day Code Challenge, I decided to sign up to see what it was all about - with it being free, there was nothing to lose except perhaps a couple of hours of my time. Turns out I thoroughly enjoyed it & I am glad I took the plunge as it was a good, basic introduction to coding. The challenge was structured well with videos explaining the basics of HTML, css & JavaScript and after each there was usually a practical challenge where you could apply the principals explained in the video. You also have access to a Slack group where you can get assistance and ask questions if needed, although I didn’t personally use this as I found everything covered was really straightforward.  I’d say I spent approx 30-45 mins each day on this over the 5 days. It’s not possible to progress any quicker and complete the whole thing in one or two days as there is only one section unlocked per day. Towards the end of the challenge you are invited to a webinar which covers off next steps etc for those who are interested & I found this quite informative also.  All in all, if you are curious about coding & want to test the waters to see if it’s something you might enjoy / have an aptitude for, then I recommend taking the 5 day challenge.

I am a month or so into my Full Stack Software Developer Diploma and am impressed by the resources offered by CI. It is these support resources which I think make this course stand out from the rest. 
Specifically for this review, CI runs occasional Hackathons, where you are put into teams with other coders of varying levels to produce a project in 4-5 days. This one had a St. Patrick's Day theme. As I am relatively new to the scene, I was a little apprehensive but I need not have been. This project taught me so much, which I would not get from self learning etc. 
The biggest asset was the teamwork involved, which replicates how it would work in the real world where you are working on projects with other people. I personally took a lot from my other team members, who were more advanced than me and took the time to guide me through new areas and prepare me for what is to come.
I feel a lot more confident in my coding journey having taken part in the Hackathon and look forward to joining more in the future.

- advert was inspirational, I actually wanted to find out more about your company
- very good marketing step to allow people try your 5day free coding challenge to get a taste of your course
2. I like to develop myself in all spheres of my life, so from my point of view, I was really excited to start.
3. Your UI is very clear and I really like the idea of having an instructional video with text next to it. It could help a lot to people who are not English tongue natives.
- You provide a good support.
- I am a Visual Artist, and even though I know it's about text education, I am missing helpful visuals (not talking about well done instructional videos). By my option education should be about fun, and therefore motivation.
4. I am not sure if I would remember how to build the site from memory, but I believe with your student program, you have much more possibilities to practise, and therefore your full program students are surely more experienced. (The same principle like playing musical instruments from notes, as more practise, as more fluently played etuda, and therefore more emotional joy.)
5. I would love to continue with a full program, but the financial is not very desirable.
6. I really enjoyed clean studying in times when I actually had time for it. Instructions were clear, and I had a really pleasant experience of studying with your 5 day free coding challenge. In these 5 days, I gained overview about the principles and about simple structures of building.
I am grateful for this experience. Thank you.

Pros:
Its for free.

Cons:
5 day challenge has no challenge at all, as it is fully compleatable by doing copy paste from steps to a coding page where it literally has "type here".
And this is a humongous one: Their program that checks inputs is really bad, so bad that it is case and white space sensitive and it thinks you have a fail if the code is not 100% exactly the same as expected. Its so ridiculous that color:Orange is a mistake while color:orange is correct, while all browsers will output have same result in both cases. Same story with white spaces 1 accidental white space to many or not enough even in plain content text not even in code and it will tell you that you have a error. And in the chat most people looking for help had issues with exactly this thing some Uppercase or Lowercase some whitespace missing or in wrong place. And seeing this kind of pretty easy to fix input check issue on site that promises you to teach to become great programmers is bit ridiculous.

After the 5-day coding challenge I was compelled to apply for the Full Stack Developer course part time because I have another full-time job. I entered the course in September 2019 and finished in December 2020. The situation is I want to leave my current work for a new career and I hope this will be able to do that. The 5-day coding challenge is a good introduction to the actual course structure, with different modules laid out on different days as a sort of schedule.
Coming from a background with no knowledge of code the course is gentle in the beginning with about 1/4 of the total course working with HTML, CSS and a little Bootstrap. Then it leads on to Javascript and jQuery in the Interactive Frontend module, a particularly bumpy step for many students, this is a common thread in the Slack community but thankfully help can be gained from tutor or mentor support, even other students depending on particulars.
After half the course is done you start reading the Data Centric Module which is all about using Python and Flask with noSQL backend using mongoDB, combined with some Javascript for nice frontend features. At this point the Javascript starts to make more sense. The last module is Full Stack Frameworks with Django which is another Python framework where you will learn database modelling in SQL, and tie several api services together such as AWS, SQL, Heroku and Stripe to produce an impressive homemade project.
In each of the 4 modules you are required to produce a web app which will be examined by Code Institute, and you will be getting some impressive feedback with scores for different aspects and some interesting feedback. Since you will be doing several practice projects throughout the course you are not allowed to plagiarize but some boilerplate code or particular components can be borrowed as long as you declare it in the Readme. Readme documentation is something important and the Markup language is discussed as well.
These projects will be scored and the average of these determines your final score. For my final project I had to extend submission by 2 months (in 1 month increments) which was fine by Student Care, and these extensions do not affect your score.
On my part time schedule I mostly had to put in 1 or 2 hours per day, I could skip a day and work it up in the weekends at times, but if I lagged behind I could always call in to the Student Care team who were always very relaxed with requests of extension.
Last but not least the price tag is indeed a treshold, but I think it's a comparably good price for the available support, they keep calling to check up on you, and there is also one-on-one tutor support available, mentor sessions for the examina projects and helpful staff available in the Slack Channel as well as other students who were sometimes able to help me. Even though the Student Care is not about learning I have to mention that there are some gentle souls working there who are always nice to talk to.
I am currently in the "Careers" module which is a nice addition since many of the students are looking for career changes.
There are webinars with invited tech companies and experts willing to look over your documentation and do a mock interview, and it's all there for your help.
So in final words, I would rate the course at 5/5 even though it's a bumpy ride entering functional programming, but it's because of the nature of backend programming. I would recommend the course for anyone, if you can manage the 5-day coding challenge.

I participated in the 5 Day Coding Challenge to get some insight on HTML and CSS.
The video lectures were easy to understand, aided with some very neat slides visualizing the information. However, the transcripts' quality was somewhat inconsistent: sometimes, punctuation was non-existent, making it difficult to separate the sentences of the transcript without the audio. Other times, there was no transcript at all (not that the transcript was necessary to understand the gist of the lectures).
The challenges were enjoyable, as I could clearly see that my knowledge was building up as I progressed through them. One small annoyance for me was the lack of guide for the syntax of HTML coding - by that I mean whether I had to use quotes or not for example. (I used Chrome on Windows 10 and I eventually figured it out by trial-and-error for each challenge, but I still have no idea when I need to use quotes)
I did not use Slack that much, but it might have helped me figure out why submitting the quiz was so buggy - I clicked the 'Submit' button, but I did not receive immediate feedback on whether I guessed correctly. It just displayed something like 'Submitting quiz', as if it was processing my answer (for an eternity)
Overall, my initial expectations were clearly met with the '5 Day Coding Challenge', even if some minor issues came up during my experience.

The course offered is quite thorough and covers a lot of new material that other courses were not offering. The course isn't really better than other learning materials. I found that freecodecamp actually gave me a better understanding of Javascript than their course did. Considering I've paid thousands of euros for it, I have to say I am a little bit disappointed in that department. 
Student support is easily accessible but shallow. Check ups over phone are easy going and friendly and all that but add absolutely no substance. Superficiality is their specialty. Advertisement is their strongest department by far. It is after all, a private company and not a university. Don't expect any real dedication to education. They just want your money. [I previously stated that 24 hour tutoring support wasn't available for 1 month out of 3 that I was on the course for. Turns out that this was less substantial than I remembered but was true for one period of about a week early in December and one period early in September.] Their preferred channel for getting help (Slack) is just far too slow unless you want to spend hours doing something which should really only take ten minutes. Getting stuck on something at the wrong time thus means you might just be stuck. The only functional tool for me was searching the history of the various slack channels hoping someone had had the same problem as me. The only hint you are ever given on a challenge is that the tools for the solution can be found in lesson x, which often isn’t the case at all. 
Maybe other people have had better experiences with their mentors but mine seemed either stressed or tired, or both, on all occasions. Perhaps people who work all day shouldn't spend their entire evenings giving advice and helping people. One mentoring session he only managed to confuse me and actually ruined the logical integrity of the code that I had written, giving me hours of work just to get back to where I was before (as I understood nothing of what he was doing but was trusting him blindly). As the course itself is hardly any better than can be found online for free or for much smaller fees at other places, this is basically what you're paying for in terms of substance. 20 allocated hours, no matter how good your mentor is, simply cannot be worth 6000 euros.  
I left the course early and they were kind enough to forfeit part of the tuition in spite of having no contractual obligation to do so. However, once I left the issues didn't end. Their communication over the leaving period was slow and the way they formulated themselves was [--always ambiguous to the point of trying to keep me on and not having to deal with-- edit: more precisely student support and finance office gave me contradictory indications early on and finance communication was slow and ineffective and almost landed me in extra financial trouble afterwards, asking for an extra instalment of the tuition whilst at the same time wanting to cut off my financing from CSN late on the 23rd of December before I had received the money for that instalment, and where I would not have been able to sort any personal financing alternatives over Christmas. Needless to say I had to postpone the final decision another week for administrative purposes even though I would have wanted to quit earlier and started expressing that in the beginning of December.]. Once I pushed them though things went through and I guess they really only forfeited the outstanding tuition as CSN (Swedish student loan services) stand as guarantors on the fees and I can at any time tell them that I am no longer studying and thereby no longer even be able to pay. More than two weeks have past since I left and they haven't supplied me with the documents that I have requested upon leaving [edit: and which they promised to supply more than three weeks ago now]. The Finance Manager is not replying my emails and I can only say that I've left the course feeling incredibly bitter about everything and regretting the experience wholeheartedly. If you want to learn how to code, there are much better options than the Code Institute.
Extra: Code Institute have written that they refute my claims. On one point I will after review retract what I said and have explained that above. On another point a clarification was necessary. The rest of it is simply me sharing my experience, and subjective as it is, it is however also absolutely irrefutable by nature of what it is. The review was also flagged by the Code Institute "because they believe it contains harmful or illegal content" which seems like a slightly excessive reaction. At least they are quick enough to reply and react to things which might affect their reputation and they haven't been trying to call me this much since the period I started the course...

Have always been interested by coding but only recently got involved; there is a starting point for everything and this was just what I was looking for in hindsight. Recently filled out a careers survey which suggested IT is my most suitable career, which actually doesn't surprise me so much: however, I don't discuss it socially, and (unusually) reluctant to order books for research purposes as was evidently looking for something more operational. 
One of the great things about this course is despite being a complete beginner it does what any good starter course would do and introduces the student to the basics (core languages covered include HTML, CSS and JavaScript) and making it clear what works and what doesn't. For someone such as myself submitting something that doesn't work (on day two repeatedly) can be daunting. however literally by the end of the day everything was completed to the correct standard. Getting everything done on the day, via research or even trial and error, was a key strength of this course: honestly can't remember if everything *had* to be done on the day in question, but in this instance I didn't allow the assignments to overrun.
Always felt there was a lot of support on offer both from tutors and fellow students although ultimately saw in the last year my current decade in my garage with a laptop and music rig for five days until everything had been done; it's hard to realise that can now actually code, albeit provisionally. The after-course support has been very positive & proactive and while I did consider four stars (five stars can be a bit of a cliché) couldn't think of anything off-putting about it; the key thing is being able to understand everything and make progress appropriately which this was well designed for achieving. Grateful to have been able to do it; considering a career change and doing my research.
The 5-day challenge was fantastic, I really enjoyed it and wish there was a bit more middle ground between that and the part time course available thereafter!

I have completed the 9-month Full-Stack Web Development Course, so my review is based on that, not the 10-day coding challenge. I did this course from October 2019 to final submission in July 2020 (And some optional re-submissions to raise my grade after). I scored a First Class Honours. It was a programming rollercoaster. If you are considering this course, be ready for the ride.
Overall, I found the course fantastic in what it teaches, if you are willing to commit yourself. Now that I've finished, I believe there is no programming language I cannot take on and learn to be competent in after a few months. It gave me that ability, that confidence and the know-how. That's potent. I would give it five stars just for that, but there are some serious faults which I am going to address first.
Good-to-know Details:
- Languages: HTML, CSS, Javascript and Python
- Other stuff: Bootstrap, Materialize (should be removed IMO), MongoDB, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Flask, Django. 
- Can be completed entirely online.
- Support is through phone, email, chat and Slack. Some support is 24/7. Covers from course info to tech and career support.
- Course duration can vary, either 9-month or one year. It depends on your method of entry.
- Cost is €6500. You can also apply through Springboard in Ireland. It will lower the cost to €600 (or free) depending on your circumstances. They request previous experience for acceptance.
Cons:
- Disorder: some lessons are a bit messy, useful course material is scattered throughout their support systems, etc. The worst con for me was this.
- Support is inconsistent. Some brilliant, others useless, or redirect you to other supports, that also redirect you. You can tell nearly everyone works remotely.
- At times, you are really on your own. You must have the will to drive yourself.
- Grading is inconsistent. It's more like a lottery than a coherent system. Their own example projects wouldn't get the mark they indicate. I made a very long complaint about it. I heard they have since updated it.
- Lots of material needs a refresh. It's still relevant learning, but they've updated the systems they use to teach, and the videos have not followed suit.
- The course material isn't always up to the level they expect you to reproduce for a project.
Neutral:
-  The course is often updated. It would be a Pro if they prepared the updates better. They've recently created one of the highest quality modules I've seen online. At the same time, they changed online IDE mid-course, didn't update the videos and just let students be the debuggers when they encountered problems. Not Cool.
- They leave you to your own devices. Pace, project design, topics etc. Double-edged sword. I liked it except for when it came to inconsistent grading. Giving free-reign for project design but expecting set requirements for the project was a contradiction in my experience.
- The course is intensive; more intensive than difficult.
- Self-drive required.
Pros:
- European University Credits, one of the only University rated online Bootcamps (maybe the only one)
- Course material is well-balanced and thorough.
- Genuinely useful test projects make up part of the course.
- Useful Milestone feedback.
- The overall teaching arch is well thought out. By the end of the course, I was programming things in days that had taken me weeks in the beginning. Understanding is built step-by-step, and you experience your own progress.
- Builds self-confidence, capability and outside-the-box skills as a programmer.
- Teaches you to use all available real-world supports and resources available.
- Can build a fully-fledged e-commerce site by the end of the course.
- Learn four languages, and several frameworks, DBs and libraries. I ended up learning plenty of things that are not present in the course. 
- By the end, you have learned great learning methods you can use to teach yourself any Programming language or framework. And have the confidence to do so.
- Lots of seminars, web-chats, lessons, etc.
- Extra-curricular projects run frequently.
- Staff and support are friendly.
- Lots of support channels, some 24/7.
- Phone and career support is of the highest quality.
- Career support will check in every so often after finishing the course.
- Take feedback very seriously and do act on it.
- They provide an Online IDE. You can finish the course only online if you choose, no installs required. I did the whole course on a 2014 (Verge of Death) Chromebook.
All in all, I highly recommend this course to anyone willing to push themselves for max potential. You will learn beyond the scope of your expectations. Be ready to work.

I'll keep this very short:
After being unemployed for a while, I wanted to turn my life around. Talking to a "Learning People" rep (they are partnered), they said that a CodeInstitute course would be great for me and my prior knowledge of HTML, CSS and other languages.
Turns out, the course I paid for is literally for beginners who know absolutely nothing about coding or even how to setup a coding environment!
It's made up of a series of unlisted videos on YouTube that I explicitly stated I DON'T like, because I don't learn well from this format.
Can't just back out because contractually, the moment you LOG IN TO THE SITE (the first thing anyone does!!), all refunds are void.
Maybe give this a go if you're a complete newbie. If you have any previous knowledge (even if it's just basic programming from school) DON'T GIVE THEM YOUR MONEY!!!

A generally helpful course, but with a few annoying aspects. The course leads you through creating a webpage, but after typing in all your custom content (in this case a food recipe), you move on to the next stage and all of your code is gone, replaced with the default, "How to make tea" recipe. This happens at every stage, so unless you keep a copy of your code and paste it every time, it's easier but less fulfilling to make the default "Tea" recipe page.
Because a lot of the information is contained in videos, you often find yourself switching back and forth between the coding page and the previous video page fighting with the video's navigation bar, instead of having the material to hand on the same page. This can become frustrating if you have just forgotten a small detail like where a : or > should go.
The integration of font awesome is based on the old 4.7 version, which can cause issues if you try to use the up-to-date v5.0 or its icons, which are incompatible and will be marked as incorrect even if you do use it successfully.
The whole course is littered with typos, and although not within the code it still leaves you wondering if the full-price course is equally lackadaisical in its presentation.
So all-in-all, there is definitely good material here and while I do appreciate that this is a free course, it's lacking the polish and ease-of-use of some of its rivals.

The explanations were mostly clear, and the tasks were not too hard to do, which is perfect to get complete beginners into software development. However, I must admit I was a little disappointed in the last exercise on day 5, as I would have preferred writing out a code rather than simply copy-pasting it from the instructions. Would have been nice to feel my brain work a little more. 
Otherwise, a great course, and doesn't take too much time to complete, so would definitely recommend to someone who's simply looking to see if they would find HTML, CSS and Java interesting to further develop skills.

Started and completed the 5 day coding challenge last week, really enjoyed the whole experience. The course is put together with beginners in mind and eases you in gently with good, informative tutorial videos, then follows into enjoyable challenges to give you a good hands on approach to coding. Another great aspect to the whole thing is the encouragement to join and be a part of the Slack community. This is where you can message and interact with other participants who are doing or have done the 5 day challenge, and together work through aspects of the challenges that have stopped some in their tracks. Spotting a fault in someone else's code is very gratifying and of course is of huge help to those who are stuck.
I haven't really any faults with the course, perhaps it could be longer (?!?), and would definitely encourage anyone who's interested or intrigued by the world of coding to give it a go, 1 hour a day for 5 days, what is there to lose!!!!

I gave the 5 Day Coding Challenge a go and I loved it! The videos are very well structured and simplified. I highly recommend giving the 5 Day Challenge a go if you want to become a Software Developer.

This course offered the perfect blend between online learning and self-directed learning for me.  I am not sure how other people learn, but I need to discover things for myself; I need to encounter problems and find my own solutions to them.
The course material offered provided me with a basic understanding of the subject and, at times, suggested areas for self-directed learning.  The Milestone Projects and the errors I encountered (especially the errors I encountered) was an education in and of itself.
It was hard, oh boy was it hard.  I had zero programming experience and had to work full-time, but I was determined to learn software development, so I put the work in.  And, it was worth it.
As to the support, well, I'm a bit of a loner, that's just me, but there is support by the bucket load, tutors, student support, slack channels, phone check-ins and mentors.  Even though I rarely used the supports, I never felt alone; I knew they were there, that was enough.
The course I give it a 5 - it pushed me, it pushed me hard; the student support, I give a 5 star.

I have always wanted to learn to code, both as a personal and professional achievement, and when I first came across the Code Institute full-stack developer course I thought I found the right place to do it.

Competent and friendly teams are also constantly available via direct lines and webinars to offer support and guidance starting from the decision-making - so that even novices in coding (as I was) can better understand whether such a career path suits them - up to landing in a new job.
Even more, they offer everyone the chance to get to familiarize with both the subject and the didactics for free via their weekly 5-Day Coding Challenge. Taking part in the Coding Challenge really helped me making up my mind and starting the course. And I am still very happy with it.

I wanted to change career and got in touch with learning people in conjunction with The Code Institute and I was sold a full stack web development course. My Son was Just about 10 months old and I felt I needed to make some changes to provide a better life for him. I was also buying house at the same time, so needed some time to steer fully clear of all the financial; pitfalls  that come with buying a house I also work full time and we are a single income family with low income (I still do and we still are). 
However the (now looking back very unscrupulous) salesman offered me a discount to the course, saying that The price of the course would go up the week after. So weighing things up I felt that saving was important to me. so I paid £4500 (everything I had in savings after the deposit and other payment for the house purchase). literally every single penny. I was assured that I could study at my own pace and that if I needed, extensions were available.
So I started the course, my wife was diagnosed with post natal depression and the time I had to put in to the course was very limited as I am working full time and caring for a my son who is barely a toddler. For the next 8 months or so, this is the case and despite me signing a contract saying I would receive regular contact from mentors, I hear not a peep from anyone. 
So my wife is better and I start to make headway with the course. A few months later my wife is diagnosed with a condition called Hyperemesis gravidarum that means she is is very very sick for the whole pregnancy (same as her first pregnancy with our son). This again limits my ability to complete the course Until the baby is born as I am caring for a sick wife and also our son. Our son starts pre-school, this frees up a small window of time for me to start my course again. However my time to complete the course is up (despite being given assurances that I could "study at my own pace"- don't believe me? It is still the exact wording used in code institute adverts that I am bombarded with on Facebook).
I pay £1200 for 6 month extension, in instalments - I genuinely do not have the money this time, I have changed jobs and taken a pay cut to reduce the amount of stress from work as I have family commitments and want to finish my course desperately. Only God knows how I pass the credit check to achieve this and I prayed the whole few minutes it took to process that application. In hindsight i should have cut my losses there but I was desperate to finish my course, desperate for a better life and these guys knew how to take advantage of me. I start my course again as all my previous work is deleted.
My 2nd child is born. My wife is feeling better, but again soon she is suffering from post natal depression. I am trying to keep everything together I make good progress with my course, then lockdown starts and My son cannot attend pre-school anymore so Time to complete the course is a premium. Last week my 6 month extension ran out (I did not receive any support from these mysterious mentors during this time either) and both Learning people and Code institute refused to give me any further time to complete my course. So I have no qualifications, and I lost my life savings. I get paid £10/hour. 
The conversation that I had with both these organisations a few days ago was deeply upsetting for me and I pretty much feel like a condemned man. I was told by learning people that there was no chance of paying for a further extensions as they had a "moral obligation" not to give it to me, but literally in the same sentence and breath offered me two other courses worth £2500 and £6000. 
In the end all my experience can do is act as a cautionary tale, because there is literally nothing I can do against this corporate block of an organisation who wanted my money and got it all. The only gain I have is that I now understand that neither of these organisations really care if you progress or make it within the IT field. The education provided is poor and there little if any duty of care to the student.

It was a bit too easy to get the Diploma for the course that includes HTML5, JS and CSS3 (5 Day Coding Challenge Course). The code challenges that was given to you after watching a video, was basically the video they did.
So in order to complete the challenges, one could basically just copy what they did in the video. That itself reduces the learning curve in my opinion. Now, people could argue that you could chose not to copy what they do in the video and instead do it by memory or using google. But let's be real, people are lazy and if there's a chance for a shortcut, people usually take it.
However, this could easily be improved (in my opinion) by adding some extra challenges to the code, or having deliberate errors that people would need to fix within the code itself before it works as intended.
All in all, the diploma is great to have. I just feel like I haven't earned it because it was too easy. I might add that I actually have an M.Sc in Computer Science but I feel like even without it, this was a bit too easy.
The CSS part was actually really good though.
All in all, I love what they do with Code Institute and I don't know how the skill level of the other courses are, but this was my review after taking my first course.

I completed the five day challenge with Code Institute. It was a great introduction (if a little easy at times), with very cleanly laid out instructions and clear explanations. After I'd completed the challenge, Code Institute contacted me to see if I would like to undertake one of their paid courses, but I felt under no pressure or contract to do so.

The 5DC was well structured and fun to do. However, distance learning means for the CI (and many others) delivering video lessons, providing a forum for mutual support and a mentor sometimes (not sure many hours). Therefore -- in my understanding -- it is a self taught course with video tutorials and some human support. There is no live interaction with a tutor.
Similar educational videos for the course are available from other vendors at about 20-40 EUR each, of even cheaper with a subscription. That is why I think that nearly 6,000 EUR is a bit too much for the CI course.
 For examples, the videos in total could cost 150-200 EUR plus 52 hours (one hour per week) of mentorship at 25 EUR/hour = 1,300 EURO, total MAX 1,500 EUR. With CI overheads, profit, etc could be reasonable of it was 2,500 - 3,000 EUR. Which is half of its current price. Too bad.

Really good and easy to understand. Even if at times it got a little complex or I didn't understand the challenge I was able to go back to the place in the videos that explained it. The subtitles at the right hand makes it easy to keep track of where certain instructions are in each video. The challenges were great because making you do the code as well yourself and at times giving you liberty to add your own spin gave a greater understanding of how to code. The quizzes at the end of each days challenge were also very helpful. And in no time you can look back and be proud of the knowledge you've accumulated. Overall it's a great 5 day challenge and it's definitely very worth giving a try.

Amazing experience ! I just wanted to share with you here, how I found out myself during 5 Day Coding Challenge created by Code Institute. I am a person who wants to change career path. In recent months, for obvious reasons, there have been very many advertisements about web design training. Recently I was looking for information about how to best gain knowledge of coding and how to find a correct learning source. One day on my FB profile appeared info about CI 5-day coding challenge. I just signed up to verify and check if this might be something for me. I studied the information available on their website and I really liked what I saw. As a person without complete experience in the field of hi-tech, I need a compendium of knowledge that will provide me with access to reliable and updated information, care and experience of the best specialists on the market, and formal confirmation as a certificate. I assumed that Code Institute provide a lot of support for their students and this is exactly what code-newbies need. My impressions of the 5 day challenge are only but very positive. After registering, you will receive a link to the educational platform by e-mail. Then on the first day you will receive a video with a summary of the knowledge you need. Next to the audio-video version there is a text on the screen that allows novices to follow the teacher, kind of subtitles for the movie, which I find very helpful. Then you get a task to solve and an example of how the final result should look like. There is also a short quiz at the end of each module. The 5-day challenge is designed to create your first interactive website with minimal time, using the basics of 3 languages ​​HTML, CSS and JavaScript. The challenge says that an hour a day is enough to study the materials and complete the task. In my case it took longer, but I consider that I am a beginner and have no coding experience or basics and my English level is not tech specific. Each day was an adventure that brought a visual final result - simple website. I decided to challenge myself and following the tips I tried to do own web instead of recreating what was given. I was able to complete the task successfully. It gave me more motivation and confirmation that I could possibly try to enter the IT industry. I forgot to mention that you can consult your teachers and other students on the slack chat platform, if you have any doubts about solving tasks or other technical problems. During the challenge, you also have access to support from career advisers and I find the contact with them professional, wonderful and very motivating. To sum up, I think that the 5 day challenge is a kind of introduction to what the bootkamp will look like step by step. For 5 days you become a student at the Code Institute, which can be very helpful if you want to find out if this form of learning suits you. There are many advantages. You can adjust your study time to the free time you have and want to spend on learning, it's very flexible here. You get all possible materials and access to continuous support, clearly defined instructions and an assessment of your results. Knowledge that Code Institute has accumulated in its proprietary courses was created in cooperation with many industry specialists, which ensures that you have access to a good source of information. I think important is that after completing the course you receive a university-level confirmation and certificate, which is still required in many companies to receive an invitation to a work interview. From here, I would like to thank you for the opportunity to participate in this interesting challenge experience. I recommend it to anyone who has doubts or is considering a career path in IT or also for the cyber adventure itself. Thank you very much to Code Institute for sharing knowledge and experience on such a large scale. I wish everyone, teachers, advisors, coworkers, graduates and future students every success in every field.

I enjoyed the example contents and practical testing. The encouragement of self-expression and experimenting with elements really gives it a fun and engaging experience.

Last Update
The project has been finally assessed, after having to chase the team. Yes, you get a response from the student care team to a negative review you leave here or there, asking if there was anything they can do to help rectify any bad feelings. Once you make a suggestion, they bluntly turn you down.
My suggestion, or question, was how to go from here, after the end of your £6000 subscription, and how to submit the remaining mile stone project. Putting in mind that I stated that tutor support was not needed, as I rarely relied on tutors support anyway and found it more comfortable and easier finding and understanding answers on the web, the answer I got was: ‘As your access to the course has been removed we won't accept or assess any further projects.’
No way forward, not even for additional fees. We have your money; your subscription is over, go away and don’t come back. 
However, a valuable piece of advice was given by the customer care team: ‘Use systems like Free Code Camp to continue to build on the skills you've developed with us.’ 
Though I developed my skills despite their poor course material and so called ‘mentor support’, this the way forward for anyone wants to pay the code institute thousands of pounds. Simply don’t! The web is full of great stuff, better structured and explained, either for free or for a tiny fraction of what those guys charge you. 
--------
Update:
Thank for your answer. 
I find it quite disappointing that the project I have spent a few months working on has not yet been assessed despite being submitted more than 4 weeks ago. I cannot help but feeling being let down by the team. I am not sure how to go forward from here.
----- 
Full stack developer course is expensive for the time limit, poor course material and not at all enough on its own, better free online resources and much cheaper individual courses with support offer better and more finance friendly options than code institute. Below average student support if not poor, good follow up for issues though, figure-it-out-yourself approach gone too far when you pay £6000 for 14 months subscription, sales people convince customers support is great with constant follow up phone calls and freezing account when no activity is detected for 3 weeks to encourage students to engage with course material, none of that happened. Towards the end of the subscription you are left to your own devices. Tutors support is poor, call times are limited and inflexible, tutors role is unclear and generally fruitless.  Poor overall experience, positive side is providing course structure; however you can find this for fraction of the price elsewhere. A whole amount of £6000 has gone for the most part to waste when much better customer friendly alternatives are available online.

I'm happy with the 5DCC. The YouTube videos that accompanied the written notes, explaining and often demonstrating what should be done and how it should be done, was really helpful especially for me who had no knowledge of HTML, CSS and JAVASCRIPT prior to the 5DCC.
Further, I want to commend the idea of the checkboxes while doing the challenges. It was really helpful for me as a beginner to know which step in a particular challenge that I have done right and when I have successfully completed a particular challenge. Also, the quizzes at the end of each day's challenge was good.

I took the Code Institute Five Day Challenge in HTML, CSS, and Javascript. The promise is that it would give me a basic understanding of the programming languages and a sense of whether I would enjoy learning how to code and being a programmer.
It definitely succeeded. I was a little concerned about how I would learn enough in 1 hour a day and how I would complete the project work and how my work would be evaluated. I need not have worried. 
I gained a taste for it, and I want more. 
The course was well structured in nice bite-sized pieces, well explained, and with great support, and was very "do-able". The customer service was top rate as well. 
If I had to pick a gripe - the video transcriptions could do with a little editing. As if often the case, some words were mistranscribed. Some of the technical terminologies could be a little hard to grasp at the beginning because often the technical phrases ran into each other, sometimes making a sentence difficult to grasp. 
It probably did take me more than an hour each day, but that may be because I'm slow at this. Hopefully, my speed will improve. 
But these are all really tiny, tiny gripes. 
I'd highly recommend the Code Institute and the Five Day Challenge

The 5 Day course gave great teachings of the material and how HTML works. The course was delivered in bite size parts that split it up into easy steps to understand and didn't stress me out. The assignments weren't overly taxing and the steps to complete them were very clear and helpful.
The material was easy to learn, however while there were assignments that had to be completed I believe a larger test at the end which involved building the recipe website fresh from scratch would have made me absorb the material more thoroughly and with hold the teachings longer.

The challenge was great! I learned by listening, pausing, taking notes, listening and so on! You must have the willingness and commitment  to learn, and then reflect that into the challenges. If you process well the information from the videos then you can complete it easily, but is all up to you!
 I gave it a 4 because I would prefer it to be more didactic, it is something missing in terms of how is presented to the student: maybe the redaction or the punctuation. Anyway it was great! It opened my curiosity for coding even more and I am exited to get into the programming world!
Well explained, I liked too much en it was so excited. The assignments were simple and easy to do, just doing what was explained.
Really enjoyed this 5 days challenge! Gave me good feeling!

Very good introduction to coding, it give a challenge for beginners without being too difficult.

The introduction was great. The resources, materials, and availabaility of people on the slack chat system was great.
The difficulty curve of lesson 5's video content suddenly jumped, with explanations of event handlers and the like. I understood it with a prior coding background.
I want to get back into software development after 6-7 years out of it. But will be doing it on my own learning, as funds are limited.

The course was excellent, I really enjoyed it.. I'm not going to lie though, there was a point in day 2 where I thought this definitely wasn't for me, but I stuck with it, went back and watched the tutorial again and I got the answer I needed. Im so happy I did that and completed the course, I would recommend it to anyone who is even curious about web development. Definitely 5 stars!!
Very well presented, excellent for beginners as the steps are walked through, explained, and the syntax is described. this much better than I have seen on other platforms.

Overall the 5 day coding challenge was excellent. There was a good combination of videos, challenges and quizzes that allowed me to take in a lot of information and then solidify that knowledge in a practical way. Its amazing how much I've learned in such a short time. 
My only issues were on days 2 and 5. On day two, the instructional videos felt vague, covering a broad topic rather than a step by step guide of a specific example. I completed the challenges but it was harder to follow and lead to some frustration. 
On day 5, the code used in the video and the code I needed to input for the challenge were different. This was despite the fact that I was trying to achieve the same goal as in the video. Because of this I am unsure of which aspects need to be included and am therefore less confident with this aspect of coding. 
Despite these issues I really enjoyed the coding challenge. The teaching style was clear and the coding program ran perfectly. I would highly recommend to anyone interested in giving coding a go.
Some video instructions didn't match the written instructions, resulted in some unclear instructions here and there. Nothing major, but seems like an unnecessary extra challenge to the.. challenges.

I took a rather interesting introductory five-day course on HTML5 / CSS 3.0 / JS. I was very pleased with the quality of the selection and presentation of the material, the simplicity and clarity of each lesson, as well as professional media content. Plus to everything is the ability to type and check your web code on a separate resource. The examples of programs from the training video do not correspond a little to the current versions, but I think this is even a plus, since there is an extra opportunity to figure out the nuances yourself. Thanks to the whole team for a great job!
Interesting course and very easy to follow for the most part. I would suggest they produce a glossary of terms as a reference point for newcomers. It may help? But overall, I really did enjoy it.

Would I recommend Code Institute? No. Save your money, learn online for free.
Code Institute makes a lot of promises but are yet to deliver. The content is subpar to a lot of free content on YouTube. I would actually recommend looking at the likes of freeCodeCamp. Code Institute’s career support is non-existent, and the mentoring was, in my opinion, a waste of time, given my grades were inconsistent with my mentor’s feedback.
Be aware the majority of positive reviews here are for the free 5-day course. Quite a smart move by Code Institute to flood this page with positive reviews, for free content, drowning out those of us who invested significant sums of money but been severely let down by a lack of content, service, and engagement.
I signed up initially having taken considerable time to do my due diligence and ensure it was the right fit for me. At the time the right fit meant I could work at my own leisure. A number of months down the line I got an email informing me I had only 6 months left to complete the course. This was completely against what I had been informed as part of the sales call. There was also no stipulation of this in any 'contract'/documentation I received. I was quite annoyed about this dishonesty and after a period of back-and-forth emails we resolved the issue by extending my deadline. But again, this wasn't what I was sold.
The course content is well structured. The problem sets throughout help solidify knowledge. I found the depth of knowledge to be quite basic to be honest. I had enquired about whether algorithms and industry best practices were covered. It was confirmed they were. But honestly, by covered, they mean there is a page title with the headers. The content is massively lacking. The algorithms content I didn't even understand at the time what I was being presented with. It was an example of here's how I can do something really slow, but if I make this simple modification to the code, look how much faster it is. There were no prior and post fundamentals to detail concepts. I would advise if you're looking anything other than superficial insights, this isn't the course for you.
I found the mentoring sessions to be a waste of time. The guidance and feedback I received was inconsistent with the subsequent grades. As an example, my mentor indicated something I had produced was of a professional standard to that of his colleagues, but my grade was marginally above the median. This was consistent across a number of my projects, to the point I decided I could do no worse by not engaging my mentor. So, for my final project I decided to go it alone. The result? My best grade, by a significant margin. If that doesn't confirm the mentoring is useless, I don't know what does. To this day I'm still waiting on more detailed feedback.
Now onto the big reason I enrolled in the course... the industry connections, the promise to do everything the company can do get you a job and help kickstart a career in Software Development...
Let me first preface this by stating I come from a professional background. I did not undertake this role to start a new career because of salary. I did it because it's something I've always loved. I will be taking a big pay cut to do so. My career thus far is what would be considered fairly successful, it's just something I'm no longer interested in.
So, onto the career’s module and assistance. I completed the course in April 2020, ‘graduated’ in May 2020. Since then, I’ve had one call with the careers team. Despite my numerous attempts and emails confirming we will have follow-up calls, I'm still waiting. To be precise it's been over 6 weeks since the first call. The careers module is also mostly linking to YouTube videos that are available for free. If you’re expecting content specifically created for this course, this is not the case. 
In the first call I was asked to gather some information, which I invested a good bit of my time doing. I've created multiple CV's and Cover Letters and sent them on. The response? Nada. That's right, nothing. I've had zero feedback. I've had zero from the career’s ‘team’. Even the first call I had was cancelled last minute (7 minutes before) and rescheduled. The second time the Code Institute career's director was 15 minutes late. Terrible experience.
Where does that leave me today? I'm still trying to find a job myself. I'm actually considering enrolling in a Masters degree and taking on more debt because to be honest the bootcamp, as it stands, has been a waste of time. Everything (and more) could be learned from freeCodeCamp for FREE. The add-ons such as mentoring and careers have had zero value, and in the case of mentoring, I would argue negative value as they set me up for a fall.
NA. Error34557

A bit of background: former aviation professional with 18 years of work experience.
For two years I had contemplated a career switch to programming/IT and I first tried to achieve that through various online tutorials. No traction. What I was missing was structure. A detailed study plan and progress tracking. Clear deadlines. Real projects in a real developer environment – including the need to search for solutions myself rather than being handed everything on a plate by just coding along. I have no intention of claiming that everybody needs that to learn – the web is full of testimonials by people who self-taught themselves into successful developer careers. But I did need it, and for those reasons the self-study tutorials didn’t work for me.
What really “sold” me for the Code Institute course – even in comparison with other similar courses I had looked at – were these promises:
-	a university-credited diploma upon successful completion of the course
-	a curriculum built upon technologies in high demand by the industry,
-	four-pillar in-course support (Student Care, Tutors, personal Mentor, Slack community)
-	career support upon course completion.
The price of EUR 5500 was not negligible by any stretch, but once I had made the final decision to change careers, and comparing the above promises to other courses of similar content/scope and their prices, it was more than reasonable.
It took me 7 months to complete the course, and after these 7 months I can say that my experience has been OVERWHELMINGLY POSITIVE.  As far as I’m concerned, Code Institute has made good on every single promise they had made before the course, and then some. Without going into too much detail, Student Care (checking in on me via telephone every 6 weeks or so) and Tutor Support (available 0-24h on weekdays and 9am-5pm on weekends for any course-related question and beyond) were absolutely stellar, and the Slack community (consisting of students, alumni and some of the mentors) is incredibly friendly and supportive - I have received amazing support in the channels and made some really good friends along the way. Career support (CV/Cover Letter/LinkedIn profile tailoring advice, employer engagement) has also exceeded my expectations.
Could the course contents be improved? Of course. There is a student feedback form at the end of every module, and the course is undergoing constant improvements – just as an example, around the time I started, they changed the “official” course IDE to replace an outdated one, and around the time I was finishing, the Django module was fully remade to use Django 3, and is IMHO currently the best module in the course.  Minor bugs or problems (which can also be reported through Slack) are usually resolved (or at least worked around) within hours or days at most. 
Could there be more content? Maybe, but I think the notion of  a complete “full stack” is more than well covered with the current content: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, Bootstrap, Materialize, MySQL, MongoDB, Python, Flask, Django. I'm more than happy with the scope this course has given me, and I think I'm well-equipped to start on any path I choose, be it Frontend, Backend or Full-Stack Dev.
You will hear some people complain that there is too much self-study and outside research required, that for this price you shouldn’t need to do that. I disagree. Yes, some individual research is needed. But I say with full confidence that there is no obstacle that the course puts in front of the student that couldn’t be overcome using own efforts, Google, Tutor Support, and Slack – at least I haven’t encountered one. And I really appreciate the moments when I was forced to do some own “digging”, as these have taught me the invaluable skill of looking for solutions, asking questions and Googling properly – I know that all this sounds like a joke, but if you’ve ever talked to a programmer, you’ll know it isn’t. I’m glad I wasn’t handed all the answers on a silver platter – I truly believe it has made me a better future programmer. 
Is this course appropriate for an ABSOLUTE novice, e.g. for someone who has never used the word “variable” or doesn’t know the difference between an OS and a browser? Honestly, I don’t have a good answer to that question. I think that at least being comfortable with using a computer – that is, for more than Netflix and Wikipedia - is a prerequisite for a comfortable study. The modules do cover the fundamentals as deemed required for the subject matter, but if someone has never heard of any of them before, the learning curve may be uncomfortably steep at times and significant additional reading/research may be needed on certain topics.
For me, this course was worth every cent and every minute invested and, if I had to choose again, I would choose the same.

I spent a lot of time considering the right track and selecting the right school when I decided to dive deep into programming. I availed of the "complimentary lessons" from each of the half dozen schools comparable to Code Institute, getting a taste of their "campus," so to speak. In a nutshell, most of the schools deliver the same content: you can learn to code with nothing but the internet, if you are resourceful and eager. But what sets Code Institute apart are their platform, their people, and their style. It's totally apparent that Code Institute's online platform has been tried and tested; not a quick scramble in light of the world overhaul on home-based learning -- which was attractive to me. Their tutors are truly invested; their students (my peers) are the most international -- which was important to me. Unlike many of the other schools, Code Institute isn't trying so hard to be anything other than what it is. Advisors, teachers, staff are honest, self-aware, respectable; there's a real "campus" experience where you're encouraged to be equally independent and guided. And this was essential to me.

Technology, in any of its forms, has not been a major factor in my life.  I don't have a smartphone and didn't have any phone until 2018 when my husband insisted I got something to keep in contact with him when I'm out walking. As a schoolchild in the 1970's, my only contact with anything connected with learning about computers occurred in one mathematics class in 1974, when the newly installed school computer, which was the size of an A3 photocopier, was wheeled into the classroom, along with a table to put the box of paper on that scrolled through it,  and we participated in writing programme instructions to land a small spaceship.  We all took our turn at the keyboard to input values to control the rate of descent of our craft and we all succeeded in crashing spectacularly and killing all the occupants!! No happy press conference for us!
My next brush with technology came in 1992. There was a computer in the house and my husband had few problems understanding how to do things and if he was perplexed he would contact my brother in law who was a boffin and worked at British Telecom.My computer usage has always been on a need to know basis.  I decided that I should show some interest in technology as that could allow me to broaden the scope of my career. I worked in the Post Office and they had just introduced computers onto the counter albeit nothing to do with 'Windows', just an in house accounting package for balancing our tills. I enrolled in a night class but after two weeks I realised that a 'beginners' class still assumed that you had an understanding of language and concept around computers. The teacher thought it was 'quaint' that I was taking notes and asked if I had a bad memory! "You can always go and look at what you've done before!", he said.  "But if I don't know why or how I did it , it wont necessarily make sense for the future", I replied. He looked nonplussed, I didn't go back.  
I send and receive emails, I use Facebook to play games and keep in touch with family and friends, I can get onto the bank website to check if something has arrived or left my account, I can usually manage to order something from a website but don't shop online very often and with the help of my son I managed to join in with a virtual choir during the recent lockdown.  
The reason for this life history is to illustrate the fact that many courses, online and in person, assume that the student has some concept and language familiarity for the subject they are beginning to learn. Any course that advertises itself as an introduction or taster would be well advised to consider that among the students are a percentage of subject virgins whose knowledge only extends to being able to spell the subject title.  I find it more and more common these days that I have to learn how to do things on the computer because the world has begun to think that everyone knows how to and nobody wants to do anything any other way. 
Regarding the challenge, I would suggest a short intro in the Module, or a little more in Billy's intro email, to explain the overall process that the student will be taking part in, i.e that certain set-up elements of the page being created will already be in place and that each day they will be adding to the content. Also a statement at some point that lets the student know that they have finished all the content each day. My opinion on the institute website is probably clouded by my dislike of most websites as they have too many buttons and sections which confuses me. My best day on the course was Day 4.  The videos were good.  Someone could say that I was only copying what was done on the video. My response would be that the medium of seeing something done is how I learn best. Being able to go back to the video to take in a process several times served me well.  However, the script alongside was BRUTAL!  No punctuation is a no-no. 
Overall I did enjoy the challenge and I may continue to learn coding but not online. Thank you.

This was an introductory course to html, css and JavaScript and the combination of these.  The instructor was clear and precise, and the hands-on worked perfectly as illustration of the theory.  I know this is on an introductory level, but I wish a little more about JavaScript.  The instructor said that good programmers are lazy and reuse.  This could easily have been demonstrated in the last exercise, where it would suffice with two functions instead of four: hover("section id") and leave("section id") - a simple demonstration of parameters.
But this is just a detail.  I have no problems recommending this course as an introduction.

I took part in the 5-day coding challenge purely from intrigue. I had zero experience and no specific interest in coding. Being suddenly retrenched and  unemployed from a 17 year career due to Covid I decided to teach myself how to build a simple website for a business idea... and it was through this that I first noticed the html section in Joomla. Coincidentally an ad popped up on FB and I clicked it.... next thing I knew, I was taking part in the Code Institute's 5-Day Challenge. 
What started with an apprehensive and fearful leap into the unknown, quickly built into an excitement, and the satisfaction of completing daily challenges daily became quite addictive. The only negative point of the challenges in when the sessions ended! The challenge is overall genius as it forces you to think for yourself, while still guiding you through each module. A huge thank you to Billy and Luca for their guidance during the challenge.
I left this course inexplicably fired up with a new-found avenue, which I can, with crisp-clarity, seeing myself immersed in as a career. I am already on the next steps looking into the Diploma in Software Development.. which a week ago I would honestly have never considered in my wildest dreams.

I got in contact with Code Institute when I went to one of the open evenings in Amsterdam. Soon after this I decided to join and start on my career change.
The course itself is divided in different modules and along the way you do 4 milestone projects. Which you can showcase on your portfolio along the way.
If you are stuck you always can ask you question to the tutor support. And they will guide you in the right direction. Or there is the slack community with all the current and past students answering question. As you start on each milestone you get a assigned a mentor that will help you along the way.
Code Institute does also have hackathons  to take part in(ex: Easter, Halloween, Christmas) to get the feel of working in teams/sprints.
After your graduated you still be part of a great community!

I started the Full Stack Web Development course in February 2019 having little experience in the development field. 
I found the course interesting and challenging. It covers such a broad range of web development, giving you a great basic knowledge across the fields. 
 The course material provided was intuitive with a great mix of videos, text and quizzes. The projects I completed within the course were challenging and rewarding and a fantastic way to put what you've learnt into use immediately. 
Throughout the course the support received from my peers in Slack was outstanding - everyone helps each other in the Code Institute Community so you never feel like you are stuck on a challenge alone. 
The employees at Student Care are a delight to deal with and are encouraging and understanding. With regular check ins and phone calls they make the course a lot easier to achieve since you are studying remotely. 
I finished the course in February 2020 and I have since gained employment within the IT Industry.
I'd like to thank everyone that helped me out and gave me advice throughout the year of the course as it helped me get where I am today :)

I finished the Full Stack Web Development course offered by Code Institute some time ago. Writing a review now helps me to put my experience in perspective. The course covers a wide base of technologies and skills required in the industry. This helped me land the job that I am currently in. After a thorough grounding in html and css, the two fundamental technologies covered in this course, javascript and python open the doors to understanding a wide range of the technology ecosystem used in web development today and beyond. 
After grasping the concepts and skills covered in this course, a student has the capability moving on and extending into related areas like react, node etc. 
Useful things covered in this course include test-driven development, mobile-first development and continuous development /continuous integration.

It did for me anyway, and I'm a software developer now which is what I'd set out to do. It's an amazing feeling, and I didn't always think I'd get here. There were definitely Milestones that were difficult to reach, and prioritising the workload against work etc takes a lot of dedication. Outcomes? I went through the 5 Day Coding Challenge offered by Code Institute, advertised by the motto 'Is Coding the Right Career for You?'
Actually, the name of the challenge is way too broad and pretty misleading because it doesn't dwell on any of the coding fundamentals such as algorithms, functions, objects, etc. -- at all! Instead, it is only focused on HMTL (80%) and CSS (20%) + offers a tiniest example of JavaScript use = Front End only. A fair name for the challenge should be 5 Day Simple Web Page Creation Challenge. Do you feel the difference? Does this sound engaging in 2020? Hardly.
Then, even for the topic of web page creation, the challenge is somewhat shallow and not challenging enough (a crime for a challenge!) Personally, I haven't learned almost anything new compared to what I knew already back in 2005.
The interfaces Code Institute uses for teaching are quite intuitive and rather user-friendly, but still, I see some room for improvement. The videos are mostly too slow and monotonous; the 'enthusiastic' background music distracts a bit; the transcripts are not split into sentences. Then, the instructions for the exercises are too detailed for a challenge! People can memorize things this way, but will they learn them properly? To learn things, trial-and-error method is unavoidable -- but here, almost no room for an error is left!
My verdict: this taster course may be good either for young teens or for some people who are the direct opposite of tech-savvy. But then, what can they learn from here? Not much at all, to my mind. And worse is the fact that it doesn't make me wanna learn more using Code Institute since I don't think a paid course by CI will be considerably deeper.

Initially seen as an ad on Facebook, curiosity got the better of me and I decided to give the 5 day coding challenge a go. I already had a very basic experience using .css, and was hoping to develop on that knowledge and learn something new.
The 5 day challenge did not disappoint! The exercises were easily broken down to understandable chunks, and the interactive platform to test them out and work through the problems finding a solution was a great touch.
The setup of the challenge is simple and easy enough: each learning element is available to work at your own pace (shouldn't take more than 30-60 minutes each day) and you are also (optionally) enrolled into a forum where others are also completing the challenge. So you can communicate and share ideas/problem solving methods, or ask for help if you're stuck. This forum is also monitored by a very engaging Admin from Code Institute who proved to be a big help to many people.
If, like me, you have any experience with HTML at all before you begin, you will see that the first day is relatively easy and straightforward, and the challenges shouldn't take too long. As the days go on, complexity increases and new elements are introduced.
The most enjoyable, and valuable, thing I took away from this challenge, personally, is the fact that every step is thoroughly explained, so not only are you learning the technical "what do to", but also the "why you are doing this". It really helped build on my previous surface-level understanding of CSS.

The 5 day coding challenge was an easy and understandable insight into coding in html and css and a hint of Javascript. 
I would have prefered more directions in some of the challenges in order not to have to go so much back and forth to the video, and sometimes the level of difficulty could have been heightened a bit. But overall, great first approach to coding and quite useful.

Pros:
The course is done online, which means you can do it from home and in your own time. There is a supportive community available via Slack - comprising of other students, tutors, and mentors. The course itself includes text lessons and videos. The videos demonstrate how to use the language and provide mini projects you can set up yourself as you follow along. There are 4 Milestone projects that you have to complete, and the real learning happens while you are working on these. As mentioned above, there's plenty of support to help you get over the rough spots and reach your goal. Most importantly the Code Institute values feedback from students and continuously works to improve its course content.
Students are kept informed of Events that may be of help to them and are given Career Support as they strive to find roles to match their new skills.
Cons:
I felt the JavaScript, dc, d3, and API videos were a bit difficult to grasp, and that they were missing basic foundation information that someone with no previous exposure to them would grasp on their own. This made the projects built using these a bit more daunting. JavaScript is not the same as other programming languages and I think it would help to have an initial video explaining the differences - e.g. assigning variables by reference, asynchronous behavior. As regards dc, d3 and APIs, again I think the videos need to start with more basic information explaining the concepts involved.
